grossa e equigranular a porfirítica; (B) Bandamento magmático centimétrico e de granulação mais fina;
(C) Enclave sub-arredondado de granodiorito em dique riolítico; (D) Molibdenita grossa disseminada em
riolito intrusivo no granodiorito Jorge; (E) Plano de fratura preenchido por pirita ± molibdenita. Legenda:
(Mo) molibdenita.
82
4.3 Hospedeiras sub-vulcânicas de composição graníticas
Quartzo-feldspato pórfiro X1
O quartzo-feldspato pórfiro (Rodrigues, 2012) corresponde a um corpo sub-vulcânico
intrusivo no biotita granodiorito X1 (Fig. 3.8), mineralizado e que hospeda parte da
mineralização do depósito X1 e encontrado apenas em seus furos de sondagem. É isotrópico,
fracamente magnético, exibe tonalidade avermelhada, matriz afanítica a equigranular fina e
textura porfirítica representada por fenocristais de plagioclásio e quartzo bi-terminado que não
excedem 3mm de comprimento (Figs. 4.7A-D).
É hololeucocrático e composto por quartzo (53-58%), plagioclásio (37-55%), feldspato
potássico (<8%) e ausência de minerais máficos (Fig. 4.1). Apatita e zircão ocorrem como fases
acessórias, enquanto muscovita, epídoto, hematita, feldspato potássico, rutilo e calcita
representam fases hidrotermais. Na matriz, o quartzo é anédrico, de granulação muito fina a fina
e com contatos suturados com os demais cristais (Fig. 4.8C), enquanto o plagioclásio (tipo
oligoclásio) ocorre sericitizado em distintas intensidades de sericitização. Em adicional, o biotita
granodiorito X1 é frequentemente englobado pelo pórfiro X1 na forma de enclaves sub-angulares
a arredondados de 3 a 8 cm de dimensão (Fig. 4.8E-F).
Pórfiro União do Norte
O Pórfiro União do Norte (Assis, 2011; Assis et al., 2012), localizado nas proximidades da
Agrovila de União do Norte (Fig. 3.2), corresponde a uma unidade sub-vulcânica composta por
álcali-feldspato granito porfirítico, sienogranito porfirítico e a monzogranito porfirítico (Fig. 4.1),
com texturas micrográficas, granofírica e esferulíticas bem desenvolvidas. Ocorre na forma de
lacólitos e derrames que se dispõem ao longo de serras que se alinham na direção NE-SW (Fig.
4.9A-C). Essa unidade é intrusiva tanto na Sequência Vulcanoclástica quanto na Suíte
Granodiorítica (Fig. 3.10), a qual é tentativamente correlacionada a Suíte Intrusiva Matupá
(Assis, 2011).
A textura porfirítica é denotada tanto por fenocristais de quartzo azulado bi-terminado com
frequentes golfos de corrosão magmática quanto por feldspato (K-feldspato > plagioclásio) de até
1,4 cm de comprimento (Figs. 4.9D-E). As rochas pertencentes a essa unidade são essencialmente
compostas por quartzo (48-49%), feldspato alcalino (30-42%) e plagioclásio (3-18%), com biotita
(<2%), magnetita (<1,5%), fluorita, titanita, zircão, monazita e rutilo como fases acessórias.
83
Fig. 4.8. Quartzo-feldspato pórfiro X1: (A-B) Rocha isotrópica, com fraco magnetismo, de tonalidade
rósea a avermelhada com fenocristais de plagioclásio e quartzo biterminado imersos em matriz afanítica a
equigranular fina; (C-D) Textura pofirítica impressa por fenocristais de quartzo bi-terminado e
plagioclásio imersos em matriz afanítica a muito fina, essencialmente composta por quartzo e
plagioclásio; (E-F) Enclaves sub-angulares a sub-arredondados centimétricos do biotita granodiorito X1
são frequentemente encontrados no pórfiro X1. Fotomicrografias: C-D: polarizadores cruzados. Legenda:
(Mus) muscovita; (Pl) plagioclásio; (Qtz) quartzo.
A unidade exibe afinidades geoquímicas com as séries graníticas alcalinas de alto potássio
(granito tipo A), oxidadas, meta- a peraluminosas, ferrosas e tipicamente alojadas em ambiente
pós-colisional. Geocronologia U-Pb por LA-ICP-MS em zircão proveniente de álcali-feldspato
granitito indica idade de cristalização em 1.774 ±7.5 Ma (Miguel-Jr, 2011). No conjunto, esses
dados são indicativos de que o pórfiro seja correlacionável às manifestações epizonais da Suíte
Intrusiva Teles Pires.
84
Visto todos os tipos, estilos e padrões da alteração descritos no depósito do Francisco
estarem espacialmente associadas à presença dessa unidade, Assis (2011) propõe que seu
alojamento teria sido essencial para o surgimento, na região, do sistema magmático-hidrotermal
responsável pela gênese das mineralizações auríferas associadas a metais de base em ambiente
epitermal.

CAPÍTULO 5 .
Regime de Fluidos
Esse capítulo corresponde aos resultados e conclusões obtidas para o conjunto de dados
referentes à (1) petrografia e microtermometria de inclusões fluidas; e (2) composição isotópica
dos fluidos por meio da sistemática de isótopos estáveis, particularmente de ? 18
O e ?D em
silicatos e de ? 34
S em sulfetos.
Essa análise corresponde a uma abordagem comparativa entre os depósitos disseminados
de Au ± Cu (Luizão, X1 e Pé Quente) com os filonares de Au + metais de base (Francisco),
inseridos no setor leste da PAAF. Portanto, esse estudo tem por objetivos principais: (i) a
caracterização dos fluidos geneticamente associados aos depósitos supracitados; (ii) avaliação das
possíveis fontes dos fluidos mineralizantes, em particular o grau de envolvimento de fluidos de
derivação magmática e sua possível interação com outros tipos de fluidos (e.g. meteóricos); (iii)
avaliar de forma consistente e crítica os modelos genéticos propostos para a formação dos
depósitos auríferos do setor leste da PAAF, incluindo modelo ouro pórfiro (Moura et al. 2006;
Assis, 2011), ouro associado a sistemas intrusivos (IRGS; Paes de Barros, 2007; Silva & Abram,
2008) e sistemas epitermais (Assis, 2011).
5.1 Petrografia das inclusões fluidas
Neste trabalho foi realizada a caracterização petrográfica e microtermométrica das
populações de inclusões fluidas presentes nos depósitos Pé Quente, Luizão e Francisco. Foram
integrados a esse conjunto os dados obtidos por Trevisan (2012b), no intuito de uma abordagem
mais ampla e integrada quanto aos dados de fluidos disponíveis para os depósitos auríferos
situados na porção leste da PAAF.
No depósito do Luizão foram analisadas inclusões fluidas provenientes de quartzo
hidrotermal gerado durante a alteração fílica (muscovita fibro-radial + quartzo + clorita + sulfeto;
Fig. 3.6) que afeta as fácies sienogranítica a monzogranítica do granito Novo Mundo (Fig. 5.1A),
em setores com teores médios de 1,27 g/t de Au. Nestes setores, a pirita corresponde ao sulfeto
dominante, na qual o ouro ocorre como inclusões sub-arredondadas. A temperatura ambiente
(25°C), os principais tipos de inclusões fluidas definidas para esse depósito incluem:
86
Fig. 5.1. Proveniência das amostras de inclusões fluidas dentro das principais zonas de alteração
hidrotermal associadas ao minério: (A) Alteração com muscovita fibro-radial + quartzo + clorita + pirita
do depósito Luizão; (B) Intensa alteração sódica pervasiva com albita + quartzo hidrotermais +
megacristais disseminados de pirita, por vezes limonitizada, do depósito Pé Quente; (C) No depósito X1 o
minério está relacionado à alteração com muscovita grossa + quartzo; (D) Halo de alteração truncado por
zonas de silicificação do depósito do Francisco. LEGENDA: (Mus) muscovita; (Py) pirita; (Qtz) quartzo;
(Ser) sericita.
Tipo I: Inclusões bifásicas primárias (L + V), aleatoriamente distribuídas nos cristais de
quartzo (Figura 5.2A). Possuem dimensões entre 05 µm e 07 µm com diversificação quanto à
forma: de estiradas, recortadas (irregulares), sub-angulares até sub-arredondadas. No entanto, são
homogêneas nas proporções da razão líquido/vapor (L/V), pois exibem grau de preenchimento
(GP) na ordem de 10% a 20%.
Tipo II: Correspondem a inclusões saturadas trifásicas de natureza primária, que
geralmente contêm um cristal de saturação (L + V + S). Esse cristal possivelmente corresponda à
halita, visto as similaridades entre seus índices de refração com os das inclusões hospedeiras
(Figura 5.2B). A exemplo das inclusões do tipo I, ocorrem distribuídas de modo aleatório em
87
grandes grupos no interior dos cristais de quartzo. Exibem dimensões entre 5 µm e 7,5 µm,
formatos sub-angulares a sub-arredondados, além de homogeneidade quanto ao GP, geralmente
entre 10% e 30%.
De forma conjunta, a tipologia I é mais abundante em relação a II, porém, ambas ocorrem
simultaneamente em todas as zonas analisadas do depósito (Fig. 5.3).
No depósito Pé Quente, contudo, foram analisadas populações de inclusões fluidas
inseridas em cristais de quartzo provenientes das zonas de alteração sódica pervasiva (albita +
quartzo; Fig. 3.9) com sulfetos disseminados (Fig. 5.1B). A exemplo do depósito do Luizão,
pirita corresponde ao sulfeto dominante, na qual o ouro ocorre como inclusões sub-arredondadas
ou então, nos limites externos dos cristais. Os principais tipos de inclusões fluidas definidas para
o depósito Pé Quente, a temperatura ambiente, incluem:
Tipo I: inclusões aquosas bifásicas (L+V) primárias, que variam de sub-arredondadas a
angulosas, e com dimensões de 5 até 12 µm, além de ampla variação quanto ao GP (5 a 90%),
sugestivo de que no momento do aprisionamento da inclusão, os fluidos aquosos compunham um
estado heterogêneo constituído por mais de uma fase. Ocorrem predominantemente de modo
aleatório nos cristais de quartzo, ou de forma mais restrita, ao longo de microfraturas intra-
granulares (Fig. 5.2C). A partir dos estudos microtermométricos, é possível subdividir esse grupo
em dois outros: (tipo Ia) composto por inclusões aquosas bifásicas primárias (H2O(l) + H2O(g)), e
(tipo Ib) representado por inclusões aquosas bifásicas, porém, com pequenas concentrações de
CO2(l) dissolvido na fase aquosa.
Tipo II: inclusões aquo-carbônicas primárias constituídas por H2O(l) + CO2(l) + CO2(g) +
NaCl(l) (Fig. 5.2D) com dimensões de até 50 µm. Apresentam feições sub-arredondadas a sub-
angulosas, com tendência por formas hexagonais perfeitas no caso das inclusões de maiores
dimensões. Usualmente formam agregados aleatórios no interior dos cristais de quartzo, em
populações abundantes e sugestivas de origem primária. Subordinadamente, podem se distribuir
ao longo de microfraturas intra-cristais que por vezes se entrecortam, denotando possível origem
pseudo-secundária. O GP é heterogêneo, pois varia de 10 a 95% do volume da inclusão,
indicando aprisionamento heterogêneo de fluidos aquo-carbônicos mediante processo de
imiscibilidade. Coletivamente, essas inclusões coexistem espacialmente com as do tipo I em
88
populações no interior de cristais de quartzo ou muito subordinadamente ao longo de
microfraturas intra-granulares (Fig. 5.2E).

Fig. 5.4. Inclusões fluidas do depósito Pé Quente: (A) Esquema representativo para as tipologias de
inclusões fluidas descritas para o depósito, em que se observa a ocorrência concomitante entre as

Estudos de inclusões fluidas realizados por Trevisan (2012b) no depósito X1 revelam que
a zona de alteração fílica (muscovita fibro-radial + quartzo + sulfeto; Fig. 3.12) que afeta tanto o
biotita granodiorito quanto o quartzo-feldspato pórfiro (Fig. 5.1C), é composta por fluidos
bastante similares aos encontrados no depósito Pé Quente, que em condições ambiente (25°C),
correspondem:
Tipo I: inclusões aquosas bifásicas primárias (L + V) distribuídas em populações
aleatórias nos cristais de quartzo (Fig. 5.2F). Exibem morfologia que variam de sub-arredondadas
a angulosas e dimensões entre 6 e 20 µm. O GP é elevado e homogêneo, com variação de 80 a
95% do volume da inclusão, indicativo de aprisionamento de fluidos em condições homogêneas,
isto é, em uma única fase.
Tipo II: inclusões aquo-carbônicas primárias constituídas por H2O(l) + CO2(l) + CO2(g) +
NaCl(l) (Fig. 5.2G), com dimensões de 8 a 20 µm, formas sub-arredondadas a sub-angulosas e
que se distribuem em populações aleatórias no interior dos cristais de quartzo, ou em menor
proporção, ao longo de microfraturas intra-cristalinas que se entrecortam, possivelmente
remetentes a origem pseudo-secundária. Exibem GP que varia de 40% a 95%, sugestivo de
aprisionamento heterogêneo em processo de imiscibilidade de fluidos, a exemplo do descrito para
o depósito Pé Quente. As inclusões pertencentes a essa tipologia coexistem espacialmente com as
do tipo I, tanto em populações no interior dos cristais de quartzo quanto ao longo de
microfraturas intra-granulares (Fig. 5.2H).
Adicionalmente, veios de quartzo mineralizados em pirita + esfalerita + galena ± digenita
provenientes da zona de silicificação que se sobrepõem ao halo de alteração sericítica do depósito
do Francisco também foram analisados (Figs. 3.15 e 5.1D). A caracterização petrográfica revelou
inclusões bastante diferentes das encontradas nos depósitos anteriores, que a temperatura
ambiente incluem:
Tipo I: inclusões aquosas primárias (L + V) com dimensões que variam de 2 a 15 µm e
morfologias sub-arredondadas a angulares, que se distribuem ao longo de arranjos planares nos
cristais de quartzo, ou então, em fraturas intra-cristais (Fig. 5.2I). Essas inclusões exibem grande
variação no GP (10% a 70% do volume da inclusão; Fig. 5.2J), a exemplo do observado para a
92
maioria das inclusões aquosas bifásicas de grande parte dos depósitos auríferos da porção leste da
PAAF.

As temperaturas do eutético (Te; Fig. 5.7) obtidas para as inclusões aquosas bifásicas do
depósito Luizão apresentam valores que variam de -82,9°C a -39,1°C (moda = -62,55°C),
enquanto que para o depósito X1, esse mesmo tipo de inclusões apresenta Te entre -48,6 a -
29,7°C (moda = -43,5°C). No depósito do Francisco, o regime de fluidos, eminentemente aquoso
e bifásico, registra ampla variação nas Te, as quais estão compreendidas entre -79,4 e -42,6°C,
com moda em dois picos principais: de -57 a -55°C e entre -50 e -47°C. Para o depósito Pé
Quente, no entanto, devido à metaestabilidade observada nas inclusões, não foi possível a
obtenção das suas temperaturas do eutético.
Fig. 5.7. Gráfico de frequência para as temperaturas do eutético obtidas para as inclusões aquosas
bifásicas dos depósitos estudados.
As temperaturas para a fusão do gelo (Tfgelo; Fig. 5.8) registradas para o grupo de
inclusões aquosas bifásicas do depósito Luizão variam de -9,7°C a -1,3°C (moda = -3,6°C),
enquanto que o depósito do Francisco, novamente, apresenta grande dispersão dos dados, com
Tfgelo entre -22.9 e 0°C (moda = -5,5 a -2°C). Nos depósitos Pé Quente e X1, entretanto, são
observados dois subgrupos principais de inclusões com base na Tfgelo: (1) um subgrupo com
pequenas quantidades de CO2(l) dissolvido à fase aquosa e, portanto, com formação de clatrato
96
(inclusões tipo H2O(l) ± CO2(l)), e um (2) segundo subgrupo, eminentemente aquoso sem fases
voláteis dissolvidas à fase líquida. No depósito Pé Quente, as temperaturas de fusão do clatrato
(Tfc) registradas para o primeiro grupo (inclusões tipo I) ocorrem no intervalo de 2,3 a 9,1°C
(moda entre 7 e 8°C), enquanto que as Tfgelo referentes ao segundo subgrupo variam de -8,7 a -
0,3°C (moda = -2.5°C). No depósito X1, são observados valores semelhantes para as Tfc (6,5 a
7,9°C), porém, mais discrepantes para a Tfgelo (-25 a 0°C; moda = -19.4 a -25.8°C).
Fig. 5.8. Gráfico de frequência das temperaturas obtidas para a fusão do gelo das inclusões aquosas
bifásicas dos depósitos estudados, com maximação da área de frequência dos resultados coletados para os
depósitos Pé Quente, X1 e Luizão.
As temperaturas de homogeneização total (Thtotal; Figs. 5.9) das inclusões aquosas
bifásicas variam de 60,9°C a 185°C (moda = 129,1°C) no depósito Luizão, porém, são
ligeiramente mais elevadas para o depósito do Francisco (85,3 <Thtotal <184,2 °C), com moda
em torno dos 150-170°C. O depósito do X1, no entanto, registra Thtotal mais elevadas, entre 126,5
e 268,4°C (150° <moda <160°C).
97
Fig. 5.9. Gráfico de frequência para a temperatura de homogeneização total das inclusões aquosas
bifásicas do conjunto de depósitos analisados.
As inclusões trifásicas salinas do depósito do Luizão exibem Te entre -80°C e -41,6°C,
com maior concentração dos valores em -64,6°C. As Tfgelo variaram de -6,1 a 0,7°C (moda = -
2,63°C). Temperaturas de fusão do gelo acima dos 0°C são justificáveis devido à natureza
metaestável que o fluido pode apresentar em certos casos (Diamond, 1992). Entretanto, visto este
grupo corresponder a inclusões compostas por cristais de saturação, a sua salinidade não está em
função da Tfgelo, mas da temperatura de homogeneização do cristal de sal presente. Neste sentido,
a temperatura de dissolução do sal para essas inclusões saturadas, definido como a Thtotal, varia de
200,2° a 280,3°C (moda = 220-230°C). Em adicional, a homogeneização da bolha interna
(H2O(g)) ocorreu em torno dos 133,3°C e sempre anterior à dissolução do cristal de saturação.
Finalmente, as inclusões aquo-carbônicas do depósito Pé Quente exibem temperaturas de
fusão do CO2 (TfCO2 ) concentradas entre -57,8 e -56,1°C (-57,2 <moda <-57°C), enquanto que
para o depósito X1 (Trevisan, 2012b) essas temperaturas concentram-se no intervalo de -58,1 a -
55,4 (moda = -56°C) (Fig. 5.10). As temperaturas de fusão do clatrato (Tfclatrato), formado no
decorrer do resfriamento dessas inclusões, variam respectivamente de 5,2° a 9°C (moda = 7,2-7,7
98
°C) e de 5,8° a 9,1°C para os depósitos Pé Quente e X1 (Fig. 5.11). Em adicional, a
homogeneização do CO2 líquido (ThCO2 ) das inclusões aquo-carbônicas do depósito X1 ocorre
entre 20° e 32,3°C, com maior concentração em 31ºC, enquanto que para o depósito Pé Quente,
essas temperaturas variam de 21,9 a 31,7 °C (moda = 31,5°C). Indepententemente do depósito
em questão, essa homogeneização se processa majoritariamente para o estado líquido.
As Thtotal das inclusões aquo-carbônicas do depósito X1 distribuem-se entre 218°C e
334,6°C, com predominância em 240ºC. Em todas as inclusões analisadas, a homogeneização
total ocorre para o estado líquido.
Fig. 5.10. Gráfico de frequência para as temperaturas de fusão do CO2 para o grupo de inclusões aquo-
carbônicas provenientes dos depósitos Pé Quente e X1.
As salinidades registradas para os grupos de inclusões fluidas nos depósitos investigados
variam consideravelmente entre si (Fig. 5.12). As inclusões aquo-carbônicas do depósito Pé
Quente, por exemplo, exibem baixas salinidades, entre 2,9 e 8,3% em peso eq. NaCl, enquanto
que os valores obtidos para o depósito X1 são uniformes, porém, dentro do mesmo intervalo: de
6,1 a 8,9% em peso eq. NaCl (Fig. 5.12A). O grupo de inclusões aquosas bifásicas que
99
registraram formação de clatrato (CO2 dissolvido na fase aquosa) exibe salinidades entre 3,86-
12,95% e 3,86-9,33% em peso eq. NaCl, respectivamente para os depósitos Pé Quente e X1 (Fig.
5.12A). Contudo, maior variação foi observada entre as inclusões aquosas bifásicas sem CO2

5.4 DISCUSSÕES
5.4.1 Regime e evolução isotópica dos fluidos mineralizantes
A íntima associação espacial das zonas hidrotermalizadas e mineralizadas dos depósitos
com plútons graníticos cálcio-alcalinos do tipo I oxidados (série da magnetita), sugere que os
depósitos auríferos investigados representem sistemas magmático-hidrotermais de idade
paleoproterozóica. Nesse cenário, os estudos de inclusões fluidas demonstram que esses sistemas
magmático-hidrotermais evoluíram a partir da interação com fluidos externos, no caso: (1)
fluidos aquosos saturados de salinidades (33,6 - 37% eq. NaCl) e temperaturas (200°-280°C)
elevadas, com fluidos aquosos de salinidade baixa a moderada (2,5 - 15% eq. NaCl) e
temperaturas reduzidas (61°-185°C), a exemplo do depósito Luizão (Fig. 5.18); (2) fluidos aquo-
carbônicos de baixa salinidade (<10% peso NaCl eq.) e moderada a alta temperatura (218°-
335°C) com soluções aquosas de baixa a moderada salinidade (1 – 27% eq. NaCl) e baixa
temperatura (125°-268°C), como observado nos depósitos X1 e Pé Quente (Fig. 5.19). No
conjunto, os dados microtermométricos apontam para um sistema de mistura entre diversos tipos
de fluidos no decorrer da evolução e processo mineralizante.
Fig. 5.18. Gráfico de salinidade vs. temperatura de homogeneização total para os grupos de inclusões
fluidas do depósito Luizão.
110
Em adicional, os estudos de inclusões fluidas realizados em veios de quartzo com pirita,
esfalerita e galena do depósito do Francisco, indicam a existência de soluções eminentemente
aquosas de baixa a moderada salinidade (até 24% eq. NaCl) e temperaturas de homogeneização
total compreendidas entre 85° e 373°C, indicativas de mistura isotermal (Fig. 5.20). Em
adicional, essas inclusões fluidas exibem grande heterogeneidade quanto ao grau de
preenchimento pela fase de vapor (10-70%), sugerindo, portanto, fluidos aprisionados mediante
condição de ebulição (boiling) (Fig. 5.20).
Fig. 5.19. Gráfico de salinidade vs. temperatura de homogeneização total para os grupos de inclusões fluidas
descritos para o depósito X1 (Rodrigues, 2012; Trevisan, 2012b).
As temperaturas do eutético são importantes por indicarem a composição aproximada do
fluido contido nas inclusões (Bodnar, 2003). Neste sentido, as informações aqui fornecidas
revelam um rebaixamento das Te das inclusões aquosas bifásicas do depósito X1 em direção às
do depósito do Francisco e finalmente, para as do Luizão (Fig. 5.7). No depósito do X1, as Te
oscilam entre -29.7 e -48.6°C, sugerindo, portanto, um sistema salino de composição NaCl-
CaCl2-FeCl2-H2O-MgCl2, enquanto que aquelas do depósito do Francisco (-79.4 <Te <-42.6°C)
seriam dominantemente de composição NaCl-CaCl2-FeCl2-H2O-MgCl2. As Te obtidas para o
depósito Luizão, contudo, indicam um sistema salino de composição H2O-NaCl-CaCl2. É
111
importante salientar que os diferentes tipos de inclusões entre os depósitos estudados
apresentaram Te muito similares, não havendo, portanto, distinção de composição entre inclusões
aquosas, aquo-carbônicas e aquosas trifásicas saturadas.
Fig. 5.20. Gráfico de salinidade vs. temperatura de homogeneização total das inclusões fluidas descritas
no depósito do Francisco.
A mistura de fluidos pode ter causado modificações físico-químicas responsáveis pela
precipitação do ouro, tais como, decréscimo da temperatura e diluição (no caso do depósito
Luizão), com aumento da ƒO2 até a saturação do fluido, a depender do tipo de complexo iônico
que teria transportado esse metal. Nesse cenário, valores de ? 18
OH2O revelam que o regime de
fluidos nesses depósitos foi amplamente dominado por fluidos magmáticos, mas que teriam
interagido em diversos graus de intensidade com fluidos externos mais empobrecidos em ? 18
OH2O
(e.g. meteóricos?), em especial o depósito do Francisco (Fig. 5.14). O intervalo de 209 a 458 °C
(Tab. 5.2) obtido pela geotermometria isotópica (? 18
Oquartzo-muscovita) provavelmente reflete as
condições termais de formação dos depósitos disseminados de Au ± Cu, pois sobrepõe aos
intervalos de temperaturas de homogeneização total obtidas em inclusões aquo-carbônicas do
depósito X1 e das inclusões aquosas saturadas do depósito Luizão. Em adicional, dados de
? 18

especialmente para os depósitos Pé Quente e X1, enquanto o depósito Luizão exibe uma leve

Entretanto, os resultados isotópicos obtidos para a sericita do depósito do Francisco tornam-se
ligeira e gradativamente mais empobrecidos em ?D e ? 18

proximidade dos pontos em relação à linha da água meteórica, e (2) uma componente magmática

5.4.2 Estimativa das condições de pressão e temperatura de aprisionamento dos fluidos
As condições de pressão e temperatura calculadas para o aprisionamento das inclusões
fluidas do depósito Luizão, com base em pares de inclusões aquosas bifásicas e trifásicas salinas
indicam condições entre 110° e 130°C e de 0,9 a 1,2 kbar (3,37 <P <4,37 km de profundidade),
enquanto que para o depósito X1, pares de inclusões aquo-carbônicas e aquosas bifásicas indicam
maiores temperaturas (126,4° <T <334,6°C) e pressões (1,02 a 3,46 kbar; 3,7 <P <12,6 km de
profundidade), os quais sugerem profundidades entre 3,7 e 12,6 km. Assumpção (2013) obteve
para o depósito X1, com base na composição química da muscovita, condições semelhantes de
pressão: entre 1,2 kbar e 2,9 kb, indicativos, portanto, de profundidades ligeiramente mais rasas
do que o caso anterior: entre 3,7 e 10,5 Km. Pares de inclusões fluidas do depósito do Francisco,
contudo, indicam temperaturas (85° <T <373°C) e pressões inferiores (? 0,742 kbar), os quais
são coerentes com profundidades de no máximo 2,7 km.
Os maiores valores de pressão e temperatura encontrados para os depósitos Pé Quente e
X1 são típicos de nível crustal profundo. Neste estágio inicial, teria ocorrido separação de fases
fluidas, com geração de uma fase aquosa e outra rica em CO2, em processo de imiscibilidade e,
portanto, intensa desgaseificação da câmara magmática, visto a solubilidade do CO2 ser
inversamente proporcional à pressão (Lowenstern, 2001). Os valores intermediários de P-T
obtidos para o depósito Luizão possivelmente reflitam um estágio mais avançado da percolação
destes fluidos magmáticos-hidrotermais, os quais tornaram-se fracamente salinos, além de
perderem em estágios anteriores, a fase rica em CO2. Fato este que, aliado ao grande número de
inclusões fluidas com cristais de saturação, é sugestivo de precipitação de cristais de sais em
estágio tardio de evolução, caracterizando-se, portanto, uma maior diluição do sistema
hidrotermal. E finalmente, o depósito do Francisco corresponde àqueles com os menores valores
de pressão e temperatura obtidos pela microtermometria de inclusões fluidas. Esses resultados
possivelmetne refletem o estágio final de evolução de fluidos, em ambiente mais raso, os quais
teriam derivado da primeira etapa de descompressão da câmara magmática (second boling) e,
portanto, com maior participação de componente meteórica.

ABSTRACT
The Alta Floresta Gold Province, located in the southern portion of the Amazon Craton,
is primarily composed of plutono-volcanic sequences generated in a continental arc during the
Paleoproterozoic. Within these sequences, three main groups of plutonic rocks may be
distinguished: (1) basement and old granites; (2) granitic intrusions that range in composition
from tonalite to syeno/monzogranite and that host gold-rich deposits; and (c) subvolcanic hosts
of tonalite-monzogranite composition. These units display affinities to the calc-alkaline I-type
magnetite series granitoids, possibly derived from volcanic arc-type setting from partial melting
of lower crustal sources (metasomatized mantle). Moreover, the major granite host (Guarantã
granite) exhibits an adakite-signature interpreted as I-type magma originated from a deep crustal
level. The new SHRIMP U-Pb zircon dating shows that the crystallization ages related to the
granitic basement range from 1,980 ±8.8 Ma (Nova Guarita gneiss) to 1,978 ±8.1 Ma (foliated
tonalite), whereas those obtained to the second group are between 1,904 ±4.6 Ma (X1
granodiorite), 1,901 ±6.8 Ma (Pé Quente tonalite) and 1,863 ±4.8 Ma (Jorge granodiorite).
Isotopic compositions show that the granitoids variable TDM ages (2.34 a 2.12 Ga), low ?Nd(t)
values (-5.13 to -0.96) and highly variable ( 87
Sr/ 86
Sr)i ratios (0.70826–0.81041). In additional,
the subvolcanic rock from X1 deposit was formed at 1,773 ±5.7 Ma. The geochemical, isotopic
and geochronological data allow us to suggest that these rocks are derived from magmas with
long time of extraction from a Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic metasomatized mantle-derived
sources. These magmas might have evolved throughout a combination of fractional
crystallization with a minor crustal contamination vector processes. Collectively, these lithotypes
can be clustered into three main magmatic stages: (1) Orosirian granitic basement and older
granites; (2) Late Orosirian granodiorite-tonalite hosts intrusions; and (3) Statherian porphyries
and subvolcanics. These stages could be respectively associated to three tectonic-magmatic
events based on a volcanic arcs model: (1) (Stage I): Cuiú-Cuiú magmatic arc, from 2.1 to 1.95
Ga; (Stage II): Early Juruena magmatic arc, between 1.9 and 1.8 Ga; and (Stage III): Post-
collisional Juruena magmatic arc setting, from 1.78 to 1.75 Ga.
Keywords: Alta Floresta Gold Province, lithogeochemistry, SHRIMP zircon crystallization
ages, Sm-Nd signature, magmatic events, paleoproterozoic magmatic arc.
117
6.1 . IN T RO DU CT I ON
The Alta Floresta Gold Province (AFGP), also referred as Juruena-Teles Pires Gold
Province, lies close to the limit of the Ventuari-Tapajós and Rio Negro-Juruena geochronological
provinces in the southernmost portion of the Amazon Craton (Fig. 6.1; Silva & Abram 2008). It
extends in a NW-SE direction for over 500 km and consists of Paleoproterozoic plutonic-
volcanic sequences generated in volcanic arc settings (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et
al., 2000; Paes de Barros, 2007; Souza et al., 2005). The AFGP has historically been an important
gold-producing region in Brazil for having produced from 1980 to 1999 approximately 160 t Au
that came especially from alluvial and primary gold deposits, mostly by local artisanal
prospectors (garimpeiros; Paes de Barros 2007).
Fig. 6.1. Location of the geochronological and tectonic provinces of the Amazon Craton according the:
(A) Santos et al. (2006) and (B) Tassinari & Macambira (1999) models. The yellow grid refers to the
regional geological mapping project of the Alta Floresta Gold Province (Souza et al., 2005).
118
Three groups of primary gold deposits and occurrences have been identified in the
province (Xavier et al. 2013): (1) disseminated Au ± Cu; (2) ductile shear vein-type Au ± Cu;
and (3) brittle vein-type Au + base metals deposits. The great majority of these deposits is hosted
by tonalite-granodiorite to syenogranite intrusions or alkaline volcanic/volcaniclastic sequences,
which has been interpreted as magmatic-hydrothermal systems similar to gold-rich porphyry and
epithermal systems of Paleoproterozoic age (Paes de Barros 2007; Assis 2011; Assis et al., 2012;
Xavier et al. 2013; Assis et al., 2014). The great majority of these mineralizations is hosted by
relatively oxidized I-type, calc-alkaline, medium to high K, metaluminous to slightly
peraluminous granitic rocks (tonalite-granodiorite to syenogranite) and more subordinately in
alkaline volcanic/volcaniclastic sequences (Paes de Barros 2007; Assis 2011; Xavier et al.,
2011).
Despite its economic importance and potential for granite-hosted gold and gold-base
metal exploration, the geological framework of the AFGP is still poorly explored, in particular its
stratigraphic relationships among the plutonic-volcanic sequences. Besides, all geological data
already available for the province remain poorly integrated into a coherent tectonic model, which
complicates its tectonic evolution understanding, especially regarded to its magmatic activity
over time. For exemple, three main tectonic models have been used currently for the province: (1)
within-plate magmatism model; (2) post-collisional extensional magmatism model; and (3)
accretionary arc magmatism model. As long as the province hosts several gold-rich granite-
hosted deposits and a few of base metal-bearing deposits, which summarize over a hundred of
small sizes (<5 t) and high grade primary gold mineralization along a NW-SE striking belt, these
understanding become a key point on the ore-forming processes comprehension related to felsic
magmatism activity.
The province easternmost sector, where this study is focused, lies close to the limit of the
Ventuari-Tapajós and Rio Negro-Juruena geochronological provinces, within an area where the
basement is scarse and poorly defined, however, with distinct plutonic and volcanic sequences
that are intrusive into it. Despite these plutonic-volcanic sequences host several primary gold
deposits, only few geochronological data are avalible to them. Ergo, these units become an
important key for a better understanding of the tectonic evolution of this province segment,
especially for lying between the limit of two geochronological provinces.
119
Therefore, the objective of this work is to provide new petrographic, lithogeochemical,
SHRIMP zircon U-Pb ages and whole-rock Sm-Nd-Sr isotopes characteristics to the granitic-
gneissic basement and some well documented host rocks of granitic composition (e.g. Pé Quente
and X1 deposits), besides to reinterpret the existing U-Pb zircon ages. These data have allowed us
to: (1) Determine its crystallization ages and updating the lithostratigraphy; (2) Unravel the
igneous petrogenesis and source of magma, and finally; (3) The magmatic history of the province
easternmost portion. Altogether, these results will shed more light on the tectonic evolution
interpretation of the AFGP, and consequently, on the genesis of its gold-rich granitic systems.
6.2 . GE O LO GI C A L SE TT IN G
The AFGP lies in the southern of Amazonian Craton (Almeida, 1978), a crustal segment
stabilized at circa 1.0 Ga, divided into several predominatly NW-SE-oriented tectonic or
geochronologic provinces (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et al., 2000; Cordani &
Teixeira, 2007) and surrounded by Tucavaca (Bolivia), Araguaia-Cuiabá (Brazil) and Tocantins
(Brazil) orogenic belts (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999, 2004).
Depending on the model used, the province is located into different tectonic-
geochronological provinces, whose temporal and spatial limits differ in the Amazonian Craton
tectonic subdivision. Therefore, the AFGP can be located between the Tapajós-Parima (2.1-1.87
Ga) and Rondônia-Juruena (1.82-1.54 Ga) tectonic provinces (Santos et al., 2000; Silva &
Abram, 2008; Fig. 6.1A), but also between the Ventuari-Tapajós (1.95-1.8 Ga) and Rio Negro-
Juruena (1.8-1.55 Ga) geochronological provinces (Tassinari & Macambira 1999; Fig 6.1.B).
Regardless the adopted model, these provinces are interpreted as an ocean-continent-type
orogeny (plutonic-volcanic sequences) with shallow northwest-southeast dipping subduction,
accreted to the Archean Central Amazonian Province during the Paleo- and Mesoproterozoic (ca.
2.05 to 1.88 Ga; Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et al., 2004; Cordani & Teixeira, 2007).
TheVentuari-Tapajós Province comprises mainly syn- to post-collisional calc-alkaline granitoids
covered by sedimentary rocks, whereas the Rio Negro-Juruena Province is dominated by syn- to
post-collisional calc-alkaline and alkaline granitoids, local remnants of folded and
metamorphosed sedimentary sequences, posteriorly covered by extensive Cenozoic
sedimentation (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et al., 2000).
120
Within the province, the basement rarely outcrops and consists of tonalitic to granitic gneiss
besides migmatites, both intruded by calc-alkaline foliated granitic rocks that vary in composition
from monzogranite to tonalite (Paes de Barros, 207). U-Pb SHRIMP zircon crystallization ages from
tonalitic gneiss range from 1,992 ±7 Ma (Souza et al., 2005) to 1,984 ±7 Ma (Paes de Barros, 2007),
similar to those obtained to the Cuiú-Cuiú Complex (ca. 2.0 Ga) in the Tapajós Province (Santos et
al., 1997). Additionally, Paes de Barros (2007) dated granitic to tonalitic gneiss rocks from the
basement (single zircon Pb-evaporation) and reported ages at 2,816 ±4 Ma, suggesting a
heterogeneous basement with Archean crust fragments, so far, correlated to the Xingu Complex.
In the province easternmost portion, plutono-volcanic arc-like and volcano-sedimentary
sequences crosscut the basement and are composed of Pé Quente (1.97 Ga; Assis, 2011; Miguel-Jr,
2011); Novo Mundo (1.96 Ga; Paes de Barros, 2007); Flor da Mata and Aragão (1.93 Ga; Ramos,
2011; Miguel-Jr, 2011) granites, known as the oldest and unmetamorphosed plutons within this area.
Except for the Flor da Mata granite, all other granite rocks host disseminated or lode-type gold
mineralizations. The syn-collisional calc-alkaline rocks are composed of Nhandu granite (1.87 Ga;
Silva & Abram, 2008), Matupá Intrusive (1.87 Ga; Moura, 1998; Souza et al., 2005) and Colíder
suites (1.78 Ga; JICA/MMAJ, 2000; Silva & Abram, 2008; Pimentel, 2001), which are intrusive into
the previous units (Fig. 6.2). The latest magmatic event within the province is represented by the
post-collisional and anorogenic felsic plutono-volcanic units, mainly composed of Teles Pires
Intrusive suite (1.87 Ga; Silva & Abram, 2008). Collectively, all these sequences show affinities to
the oxidized I-type, calc-alkaline, medium to high K, magnesium, metaluminous to slightly
peraluminous granitic rocks, originated in a volcanic arc setting, except for the Teles Pires suite that,
for corresponding to the latest magmatic event, is composed of A2-type post-collisional alkaline
granites.
Overlaying all the previous sequences occur Mesoproterozoic pull-apart, maybe strike slip-type,
sedimentary basins defined as Caiabis group (Dardanelos Formation; Moreton & Martins, 2005;
Souza et al., 2005). This unit contains sandstone, arkose, siltstone, mudstone and basal conglomerate
that are interpreted as fluvial sequences surrounded by transcurrent shear zones. The maximum ages
reported to this clastic sequence are between 1,987±4 Ma and 1,377 ±13 Ma (U-Pb LA-ICP-MS
zircon; Leite & Saes, 2003). Paleozoic and Cenozoic periods are represented by laterization events
and especially by recent alluvial and colluvial deposits (Souza et al., 2005) with economic secondary
concentrations practically exhausted. A brief summary of the AFGP major stratigraphic units,
geochronology and tectonic setting is given in Fig. 6.2 and Table 1.

6.3 MA TE RI A LS A N D ME TH O DS
6.3.1 Nature of the investigated samples
Samples from the eastern sector of the AFGP investigated in this work are grouped
according to their field relationships into: (1) basement rocks; (2) granitic intrusions; and (3)
subvolcanic rocks. The first group includes the Nova Guarita gneiss and cross-cutting foliated
biotite tonalite. The second group is represented by (1) biotite tonalite and biotite granodiorite,
respectively, the main host rocks of the Pé Quente and X1 gold deposits; and (2) a granodiorite
pluton, located at Jorge quarry (town of Matupá) that contains low-grade gold mineralization
associated with disseminated pyrite and molybdenite. The subvolcanic rock group consists of a
quartz-feldspar porphyry intrusion that hosts the X1 gold deposit. For comparison purposes, this
work also includes in the subvolcanic group the quartz-feldspar porphyry spatially and genetically
associated to the Francisco gold-base metal deposit located in the União do Norte region (Fig.
6.2). In this case, petrographic, geochemical e geochronological data for this porphyry can be
found in Miguel-Jr (2011) and Assis et al. (2012), whereas Sm-Nd-Sr data were also included into
this work. Fresh samples were collected from outcrops, quarries and drill holes. Natural exposures
were available for granitic basement rocks and biotite granodiorite (Jorge quarry), whereas
samples from Pé Quente and X1 deposits were selected from drill holes (Table 6.2). Any
weathered surfaces and/or hydrothermal products (veinlets, pervasive alterations) were carefully
removed.
6.3.2 Whole rock lithogeochemistry
A total of 35 samples were selected to lithogeochemistry analyzes, from which the
basement, Pé Quente tonalite and X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry summarize eight each one, besides
seven samples from X1 granodiorite and four from Jorge granodiorite. Moreover, six samples
from Pé Quente tonalite and five from X1 granodiorite are derived from the Ramos (2011) and,
therefore, added into this suite table (Anexos 02A-E).
We used approximately 2-10 kg of material for each sample, initially reduced to 0.5-2.0 cm
diameter fragments in a steel jaw crusher (Pulverisette II from Fritsch). We have, then, pulverized
the fragments to powder below 200 meshes with a planetary ball mills. Before pulverizing each
sample, the planetary mill was cleaned with fine-grain size quartz sand. Sample preparation was
all carried out at the Instituto de Geociências (IG/UNICAMP).

Analyses for major, minor and trace elements (including rare earth elements), were carried
out by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) and inductively
coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) at Acme Analytical Laboratories Ltd. (Canada).
Total abundances of major and minor oxides are reported on a 0.2 g sample analyzed by ICP-EOS,
following a lithium metaborate (LiBO2) fusion and dilute nitric digestion. Rare earth and
refractory elements were determined by ICP-MS also following LiBO2 fusion and nitric acid
digestion of a 0.2 g sample. Moreover, a separate 0.5 g split was digested in aqua regia and
analyzed by ICP-MS for precious and base metals. Loss on ignition (LOI) was determined by
weight difference after ignition at 1.000°C. Total carbon and sulphur concentrations were
determined with a LECO elemental analyzer.
Elements systematically analyzed with ICP-OES include SiO2, Al2O3, Fe2O3 (total) MgO,
CaO, Na2O, K2O, Ti2O, P2O5, MnO and Cr2O3, whereas the ICP-MS was used to determinate Bi,
Ba, Be, Co, Cs, Ga, Hf, Nb, Rb, Sn, Sr, Ta, Th, U, V, W, Y, Zr, Ni, As, Cd, Sb, Hg, Tl, Se, Tm,
Ni, Mo, As, Bi, Cd, Hg, Mo, Ni, Sb, Se, Tl, rare earth elements (La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb,
Dy, Ho, Er, Yb, Lu), precious (Au, Ag) and base metal elements (Cu, Zn, Pb). We used certified
standard sample (BRP-1, Cotta & Enzweiler, 2008) and internal duplicate samples to monitor the
data quality and precision, produced by the laboratory. The analytical precision obtained is higher
than 96% relative to the standard deviation (RSD) for major and minor elements, and lesser than
one magnitude order for trace elements (10 1 ppm).
6.3.3 U-Pb SHRIMP IIe (zircon)
A total of nine samples (Anexos 03A-F) were analyzed by U-Pb Sensitive High Resolution
Ion Microprobe (SHRIMP IIe) zircon method from approximately 5-20 kg of fresh samples. In
this sample set, five are from basement rocks, including the Nova Guarita gneiss and foliated
biotite tonalite, four from gold-mineralized granitic plutons (Pé Quente biotite tonalite, X1 biotite
granodiorite and Jorge granodiorite), and one from quartz-feldspar porphyry from the X1 gold
deposit.
Zircon concentrates were extracted by using conventional gravity, paramagnetic and heavy
liquids techniques. Heavy minerals concentrates of <350 µm fraction were separated magnetically
by gradual current increasing as follow: 0.1A, 0.3A, 0.6A, 1.0A and 1.5A. Inclusion-free zircons
from non-magnetic fraction were then handpicked under binocular ZEISS lens. This stage was
130
carried out at the Mineral Concentration Laboratory at the Institute of Geosciences, State
University of Campinas (UNICAMP, Campinas, Brazil).
The concentrates were sent to the Laboratory of High-Resolution Geochronology of the
Institute of Geosciences, University of São Paulo (GeoLab-IGc-USP, Brazil) where the U-Pb
SHRIMP IIe zircon isotopic analyses were performed. To normalize the isotopic fractionation
during analyses the zircon concentrates were mounted together with TEMORA (Black et al.,
2003) external standard, in epoxy resin disk and polished until the crystal interiors were exposed,
and them, coated with ~100Å of gold. All zircon crystals were documented with transmitted and
reflected light micrographs as well as cathodoluminescence (CL) images in order to reveal the
sectioned grains internal structures, and then to target their inner areas, before prior U-Pb isotopic
analyses. The polished mounts were comprehensively examined with a FEI-QUANTA 250
scanning electron microscope equipped with secondary-electron and cathodoluminescence
detectors. The most common conditions used in cathodoluminescence analysis were: 60 µm of
emission current, 15.0 kV of acceleration voltage, 7 µm of beam diameter, 200 µs of acquisition
time, and a resolution of 1.024x884. Subsequently, we analyzed the same mounts by the U-Pb
isotopic technique using a SHRIMP IIe machine also at the GeoLab-IGc-USP following the
analytical procedures presented in Williams (1998). Correction for common Pb was made based
on basis of the 204
Pb measured, and the typical error component for the 206
Pb/ 238
U ratio is less than
2%; whereas the uranium abundance and U/Pb ratios were calibrated against TEMORA standard
and the age calculations were carried out with Isoplot© 3.0 (Ludwing, 2003). Uncertainties given
for individual analyses (ratio and ages) are at 2? level, however, all uncertainties in calculated
weighted mean ages are reported as 95 percent confidence limits.
6.3.4 Sm-Nd-Sr method
A total of 17 samples were selected for Sm-Nd-Sr isotopic analyses, four of which
representing the basement rocks, eight from gold-mineralized granitic plutons (Pé Quente tonalite,
X1 granodiorite and Jorge granodiorite), and five from the X1 and União do Norte quartz-feldspar
porphyry intrusions. Sample preparation was conducted at the Geochronology Laboratory of the
University of Brasília (Brasília, Brazil). Sample dissolution was performed in Teflon Savillex
beakers or Parr-type Teflon bombs. Sm and Nd extraction from whole-rock powders followed
Richard et al. (1976) technique modified by Gioia and Pimentel (2000), in which the REE
131
separation as a group using cation-exchange columns precedes reversed-phase chromatography for
separating Sm and Nd, using columns loaded with HDEHP (di-2-ethylhexeyl phosphoric acid)
supported on Teflon resin. A mixed 149
Sm- 150
Nd spike was used. Sm and Nd samples were loaded
onto Re evaporation filaments of a double filament assembly, whereas we carried out the isotopic
analyses using a Finningan MAT-262 multi-collector mass spectrometer in static mode.
Uncertainties in Sm/Nd and 143
Nd/ 144

respectively, based on repeated analyses of international rock standards NBS-987. The

6 . 4 P E T R O G R A P H Y O F T H E I N V E S T I G A T E D U N I T S
6.4.1 BASEMENT ROCKS
Rocks that represent the basement unit in the eastern sector of the AFGP are poorly exposed
and mostly represented by biotite gneiss, therein named Nova Guarita, and foliated biotite tonalite.
The Nova Guarita gneiss is pinkish to orangish, holo-leucocratic, inequigranular, medium to
coarse-grained and with millimetric banding marked by alternating quartz-feldspar bands and
biotite-rich bands (Fig. 6.3A-B). Sometimes, syn-plutonic diorite dikes are intrusive into these
rocks (Paes de Barros, 2007), or even amphibolites enclaves around 20 to 80 cm in length can be
found (Fig. 6.3C). Its main structure is an incipient to moderate millimetric metamorphic
differentiation (gneissic banding) into rich-quartz and feldspar bands which originates a weak sub-
parallel to anastomosing foliation (Sn) defined by strong brownish pleochroism, medium-grained
lepidoblastic biotite (Figs. 6.3D). The gromero-porphyroblastic texture (~5.5-8.3%) is defined of
coarse-grained microcline, plagioclase and quartz crystals which reflects a compositional banding
aligned. The mineral association is composed of quartz (34-39%), K-feldspar (33-40%; orthoclase
> microcline), plagioclase (20-25%), biotite (2-6%), whereas the accessory phases (~6%) are
constituted of titanite, apatite, zircon, magnetite and rutile, besides, sericite, muscovite, epidote,
clinozoisite, chlorite, pyrite and hematite as hydrothermal minerals. The quartz is anhedral, fine-
grained (feldspar-rich bands) to coarse-grained (quartz-rich bands), shows strong sectoral wavy
extinction (sub-grains texture), recrystallized contacts and are parallel fragmented into the
foliation. The K-feldspar often displays meso-perthitic textures. The plagioclase is anhedral to
132
sub-anhedral, is strongly sericitized and occasionally occurs as sub-rounded crystals around the K-
feldspar edges into simplectitic textures. Biotite crystals with pleochroic haloes are common.
Fig. 6.3. (A) Metric circular blocks from Nova Guarita gneiss; (B) Orangish and coarse to medium-grained
Nova Guarita gneiss with incipient millimetric metamorphic differentiation (gneissic banding); (C) Syn-
plutonic diorite dikes (~40-50 cm in length) metamorphosed into amphibolites facies in the Nova Guarita
gneiss; (D) Biotite showing brownish pleochroism within a sub-parallel foliation into the Nova Guarita
gneiss. Zircon crystals found in this rock are often related to it; (E) Intrusive contact between foliated
biotite tonalite and the Nova Guarita gneiss; (F) Accessories phases in the foliated tonalite are generally
represented by biotite, apatite, titanite and zircon. Legend: Ap: apatite; Bt: biotite; Mc: microcline; Or:
orthoclase; Pl: plagioclase; Qtz: quartz; Ttn: tinanite; Zrn: zircon.
The foliated biotite tonalite is intrusive into the Nova Guarita gneiss (Fig. 6.3E). It
corresponds to a greyish, medium to coarse-grained, inequigranular to porphyritic, anisotropic and
holo-leucocratic rock. The porphyritic texture comprises up to 10% of the rock volume and is
represented by plagioclase crystals with concave-convex and mounted contacts. Sometimes
anhedral quartz and sub-anhedral biotite fine-grained occur as inclusions within the phenocrystals.
Its mineral assemblage consists of plagioclase (46-51%), quartz (28-33%), orthoclase >>
microcline (up to 10%) and biotite (4-13%), with accessory phases (5.5-14%) represented by
133
titanite, apatite, zircon and magnetite. Sericite, epidote, clinozoisite and chlorite occur as
metasomatic minerals. Locally, K-feldspar replaces plagioclase phenocrysts marking a weak
potassic alteration. The quartz is interstitial, medium to coarse-grained, and shows weak to
moderate wavy extinction with subgrains textures. Quartz grains exhibit straight and concave-
convex contacts, and is responsible for a weakly-irregular metamorphic anisotropy along tiny
quartz-rich bands that sometimes engulf the feldspars crystals. The plagioclase is fine to medium-
grained, subhedral, shows vermiform texture at the K-feldspar contacts and is partially replaced by
fine-grained sericite along its twinning. Igneous K-feldspar forms anhedral medium-grained
crystals commonly with perthitic and vermiform textures. The biotite, sometimes replaced by iron-
rich chlorite, is subhedral, fine to medium-grained, interstitial, exhibits a strong greenish-yellow to
brownish pleochroism and imprints the rock foliation (Fig. 6.3F), indicative of regional tectonic
stress. The titanite + apatite + zircon + magnetite assemblage often occurs together with biotite as
fine to medium-grain grains.
6.4.2 GRANITIC HOST INTRUSIONS
Pé Quente biotite tonalite
The Pé Quente biotite tonalite (Assis et al., 2012; Stabile, 2012) is isotropic, medium-
grained, holo-leucocratic with inequigranular, hypidiomorphic and locally porphyritic textures
(Figs. 6.4A).The porphyritic texture (up to 10%) is represented by large and euhedral plagioclase
crystals. This rock is commonly crosscut by aplitic dikes of granodioritic composition but of
unknown age (Fig. 6.4B). The tonalite is composed of plagioclase (oligoclase composition; 40-
50%), quartz (35-40%), K-feldspar (7-10%), and biotite (~10%), with titanite, apatite, zircon,
monazite, rutile and magnetite as accessory phases (<5%). Sericite, muscovite, chlorite and
epidote are linked to post-magmatic hydrothermal processes. The plagioclase is medium-grained,
euhedral to sub-euhedral, shows planar and concave-convex contacts and exhibits a strong
oscillatory zoning with sericitized core. The quartz is anhedral, fine to medium-grained and
exhibits moderate wavy extinction. The biotite occurs as sub-euhedral and medium-grained
crystals often replaced by iron-rich chlorite.
134
Fig. 6.4. (A) Isotropic, medium-grained Pé Quente biotite tonalite; (B) Aplite dikes of granodioritic
composition that often crosscut the Pé Quente tonalite, especially close to the ore-zones; (C) Isotropic,
medium to coarse-grained X1 porphiritic granodiorite with plagioclase phenocrystals; (D) Grayish,
isotropic and coarse-grained Jorge biotite granodiorite with a milimetric pegmatitic intrusion; (E) X1
quartz-feldspar porphyry with bipyramidal quartz phenocrystals; (F) Biotite granodiorite enclaves within
X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry.
X1 biotite granodiorite
At the X1 gold deposit, the biotite granodiorite is medium to coarse-grained, isotropic, holo-
leucocratic, grayish coloured and has equigranular to porphyritic textures (Fig. 6.4C), conferred by
the presence of 1.5 to 3 cm large-euhedral phenocrysts of quartz and plagioclase. Its mineral
composition includes quartz (45-58%), oligoclase (43-50%), K-feldspar (7-15%), together with
biotite (<5%), apatite, zircon and magnetite as accessories phases, and muscovite, sericite, calcite,
K-feldspar, rutile, hematite, pyrite and rare epidote as hydrothermal minerals. The quartz is
135
interstitial, fine to medium-grained, has moderate wavy extinction and sutured contacts. The
plagioclase is sub-euhedral, medium to coarse-grained and sometimes shows oscillatory zoning
with sericitized core. The K-feldspar (mainly orthoclase-type) is anhedral to sub-euhedral, fine to
medium-grained and often shows perthitic texture and rarely mimerkitic intergrowth with quartz
and poikilitic texture with quartz and plagioclase inclusions. The biotite is fine to medium-grained,
euhedral to sub-euhedral, is often replaced by iron-rich chlorite and commonly related to
magnetite and zircon.
Jorge biotite granodiorite
The Jorge biotite granodiorite was initially described at the Jorge quarry (Matupá city, MT)
as one of the facies belonging to the Matupá Intrusive suite (Teixeira et al., 2012). At the Jorge
quarry it corresponds to a leucocratic, greyish, isotropic, coarse-grained and equigranular to
porphyritic rock (Fig. 6.4D). The phenocrysts comprise about 20-30% of the rock volume and are
represented by euhedral to sub-euhedral K-feldspar crystals, up to 5 cm in length. It is mainly
composed of quartz (40-49%), andesine (31-38%), K-feldspar (12-14%), including orthoclase and
microcline in perthitic textures, besides biotite (up to 12%), zircon, apatite, titanite, rutile,
magnetite, fluorite, monazite as accessory phases, and sericite, epidote and chlorite as
hydrothermal minerals.
Locally, this rock displays flow magmatic banding that is usually crosscut by coarse to very
coarse-grained pegmatites composed of K-feldspar and quartz, besides quartz-pyrite-
(molybdenite) veins. Fine-grained and sub-euhedral pyrite is a very common mineral that fills
quartz-veins that crosscut the lithotype. At places the granodiorite is affected by NNE and NNW
ductile-brittle shear zones. Additionally, a N50E-striking rhyolite dike intrudes the granodiorite as
laccoliths, with exposures of up to ~10 meters high, ~150 meters in length and with no evidences
of contact metamorphism. Disseminated fine-grained pyrite and some molybdenite are frequently
observed within the dike.
6.4.3 SUBVOLCANIC HOST GRANITES
X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry
This lithotype has only been observed in drill holes that intersept the gold mineralization at
the X1 deposit, where it crosscuts the X1 biotite granodiorite, as 5-20 cm thick dikes, as up to 25m
dikes (laccoliths?), or even contains enclaves of the latter. It corresponds to an isotropic and
136
porphyritic subvolcanic rock of reddish color due to its pervasive potassic (orthoclase) alteration
(Fig. 6.4E). The phenocrysts do not exceed 5-10% of the rock volume and are embedded in an
afanitic to fine-grained matrix of granular texture. They form euhedral to sub-euhedral crystals
that may reach up to 4mm in length and comprise plagioclase (oligoclase-type) and bipyramidal
bluish quartz that often exhibits corrosion gulfs. The rock modal composition includes quartz (53-
58%), plagioclase (37-55%) and K-feldspar (1-8%), besides apatite, zircon and rutile as
accessories phases, and muscovite, epidote, calcite, hematite and rutile as hydrothermal minerals.
Mafic minerals are absent. X1 granodiorite enclaves with angular shapes and dimensions ranging
from 7 to 15 cm large often recognized within the quartz-feldspat porphyry. However, there are
also found 3-8 cm large, angular-shaped quartz-feldspar porphyry enclaves enclosed into the X1
biotite granodiorite (Fig. 6.4F).
6 . 5 L I T H O GE O C H E M I S T R Y
6.5.1 Major and minor elements
Among the basement rocks, the foliated biotite tonalite exhibits a more homogeneous
distribution pattern of major and minor elements than Nova Guarita gneiss. The foliated biotite
tonalite also shows higher Al2O3 (>14.5 wt.%), Fe2O3 (>1.8 wt.%), CaO (>1.6 wt.%), Na2O (>3.6
wt.%), TiO2 (>0.22 wt.%), P2O5 (>0.08 wt.%), MgO (>0.44 wt.%) and MnO (>0.05 wt.%)
contents than Nova Guarita gneiss. The Nova Guarita gnessis, however, shows higher silica (76.5
<SiO2 <78.2 wt.%) and K2O (5-5.6 wt.%) contents than those obtained for foliated biotite
tonalite. Moreover, the MgO/(MgO+Fe2O3) ratios are higher in foliated biotite tonalite (<0.22)
than in Nova Guarita gneiss (around 0.06). Additionally, it is noteworthy that there is a SiO2
compositional gap between 72 and 76 wt.% concerning these two suites (Fig. 6.5).
Into the granitic host intrusions group, the X1 granodiorite shows the highest silica (>72.5
wt.%) and Na2O (4.1-4.8 wt.%) contents, but the lowest Fe2O3 (<1.35 wt.%), MgO (<0.39 wt.%),
CaO (<1.75 wt.%), TiO2 (<0.15 wt.%), P2O5 and MnO (both<0.05 wt.% ) contents. On the other
hand, the Jorge granodiorite exhibits the most uniform distribution patterns of these elements into
these group, as long as the highest Fe2O3 (>2.95 wt.%), MgO (>0.98 wt.%), K2O (>4.5 wt.%),
TiO2 (>0.44 wt.%), P2O5 (>0.17 wt.%), MnO (>0.06 wt.%) and Cr2O3 (~0.01 wt.%) contents,
however K2O > Na2O and the lowest Na2O (<3.26 wt.%) contents. The Pé Quente tonalite has the
137
highest CaO (>2.47 wt.%) and Al2O3 (>15.2 wt.%) contents, Na2O > K2O. All rocks belonging to
this group show low to moderate MgO/(MgO+Fe2O3) ratios, that vary from from 0.2 to 0.25.
Into the subvolcanic host granite group, the X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry shows a
homogeneous distribution patterns of these elements, is enriched in silica (>75.9 wt.%) and K2O
(K2O > Na2O), but depleted in Fe2O3 (<1.61 wt.%), TiO2 (<0.12 wt.%) MnO (<0.06 wt.%),
besides low MgO/(MgO+Fe2O3) ratios that range from from 0.07 to 0.21.
The concentration of Al2O3, Fe2O3, MgO, TiO2 and P2O5 generally decreases with
increasing silica, whereas MgO (for Jorge granodiorite), Na2O, Al2O3, MgO (for X1 quartz-
feldspar porphyry), P2O5 (for Nova Guarita gneiss) and K2O (for foliated tonalite, X1 granodiorite
and Pé Quente tonalite) increase with igneous fractionation. On the other hand, MnO and P2O5
(for X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry) remain relatively constants (Fig. 6.5).
According to the R1-R2 chemical variation diagram (De La Roche et al., 1980; Fig. 6.6A)
samples from the basement granitic group are geochemically classified as granite, whereas those
from granitic host intrusions group plot in the field of granodiorite and granite, and those from
subvolcanic host granite group are mainly of alkali-granitic composition. Moreover, in the
Winchester & Floyd (1977), samples from Nova Guarita gneiss fit into the rhyodacite and
rhyodacite/dacite interface, whereas those from foliated biotite and Jorge granodiorite fall into the
rhyodacite/dacite field, and those from X1 granodiorite, Pé Quente tonalite and X1 quartz-feldspar
porphyry plot into the trachyte andesite field (Fig. 6.6B).
6.5.2 Trace elements
In most cases, the Jorge granodiorite, X1 granodiorite and X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry
corresponds the suites whose trace elements contents exhibit the slightest variation in their values
(Fig. 6.5). In most cases, Mo, As, Cd, Sb, Bi, Ag, Au, Hg, Be, Se, Sn, V and W were below the
detection limit.
Based on LILE abundances (e.g. Rb, Cs, Sr, Ba) the foliated biotite tonalite shows higher Ba
(1.151 to 1.420 ppm) and Sr (346 to 399 ppm) values, but lower Rb (123.4 to 125.4 ppm) and Cs
(0.6-0.7 ppm) than the Nova Guarita gneiss. Among the granitic host intrusions rocks, the Pé
Quente biotite tonalite exhibits the highest Ba (1.606 to 2.122 ppm) and Sr (838 to 1.256 ppm)
contents, whereas the Jorge granodiorite exhibits the highest Cs (3.9-4.5 ppm) and Rb (194 to 201
ppm) contents. Still into this group, the Pé Quente tonalite shows the lowest Cs (<0.4 ppm) and Rb
138
(<44.7 ppm) values, whilst the Jorge granodiorite and Nova Guarita gneiss are the most depleted
in Sr (<243 ppm) and Ba (<452 ppm). Collectively, the LILE abundance (e.g. Rb, Cs, Sr, Ba) vary
systematically with differentiation (silica increasing) in all analyzed suites. Into the subvolcanic
host granite group, the X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry is enriched in Ba (608 to 1.118 ppm) and Rb
(118 to 153 ppm), but depleted in Sr (79-124 ppm) and Cs (0.3-1.7 ppm). Taken together, Rb and
Cs usually increase with silica contents, except for X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (for Rb), Nova
Guarita gneiss and Jorge gneiss (for Cs), whereas Sr and Ba decline with igneous differentiation,
saving Ba (for foliated tonalite and Pé Quente tonalite; Figs. 6.5G-L). These trends suggest the
plagioclase was the most important phase crystallized during the igneous fractionation, followed
by K-feldspar. On the basis of K/Rb ratios (Blevin, 2004), all the investigated lithotypes are
considered as strongly evolved (K/Rb ratios below 168.19), except for the Pé Quente tonalite
which presents K/Rb ratios between 286 and 352.8, within the range of moderately evolved
granites (Fig. 6.7).
Concerning the HFSE (e.g Zr, Th, Nb, U and Ta), the Nova Guarita gneiss correspond to the
basement rock whose values are most enriched compared to the foliated biotite tonalite (Fig.
6.5L). Among the granitic host intrusions group, the Jorge granodiorite shows the highest values
(Zr > 234 ppm; Th > 19.9 ppm; Nb > 14.3 ppm; U > 4 ppm and Ta > 1.3 ppm), whereas the Pé
Quente tonalite contains the lowest values (Zr <85 ppm; Nb <4.4 ppm; Th <2.6 ppm; U <0.9
ppm and Ta <0.3 ppm). According to the Harker diagram their abundances decrease with
differentiation (Fig. 6.5L), except to X1 granodiorite (for U and Nb). The X1 quartz-feldspar
porphyry, in turns, is enriched in all these elements (Zr > 69.8 ppm; Th > 10.6 ppm; Nb > 9.6
ppm; U > 3 ppm; and Ta > 0.7 ppm). The strong negative correlation between silica contents and
HFSE displayed by the Nova Guarita gneiss and X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry suggests that
minerals such zircon (Zr), columbite or Fe-Ti-rich oxides (Nb, TiO2) and apatite (P2O5) did not
crystallize until the magma was oversaturated on silica (above 75 wt.% SiO2).

In addition, since Zn and Pb values increase with igneous fractionation, their high contents
observed for all lithotypes (especially for X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry) may be attributed to the
fluid involvement. It would be more abundant within evolved and fractionated granitic systems
141
such as this case, because these elements preferentially partition themselves into a fluid phase and,
therefore, triggering hydrothermal influence of later hydrothermal fluids (Heinrich et al., 1999;
Heinrich et al., 2004).

All the investigated samples are more enriched in light rare-earth elements (?LREE) than in
heavy rare-earth elements (Fig. 6.8), with ?LREE/?HREE ranging from 6.75 to 29.48. The ?LREE
decreases from Nova Guarita gneiss (?LREE<284.1 ppm), to Jorge granodiorite (?LREE<269.6 ppm)
? foliated tonalite (?LREE<125.8 ppm) ? X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (?LREE<113.9 ppm) ? X1
granodiorite (?LREE<77.1 ppm) and Pé Quente tonalite (?LREE<100.2 ppm),. The REE patterns for

granitic rocks contain basically the same accessory phases (Fe-rich biotite, titanite and apatite).
Except the fact that Jorge granodiorite is more enriched in REE, it exhibits a very similar pattern
compared to X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (Figs. 6.8E-F).
The absent to small Eu/Eu* anomalies shown by Pé Quente tonalite (0.55 <Eu/Eu* <1.05),

that plagioclase was not important during their crystallization (Figs. 6.7B-D). On the other hand,
negative Eu anomalies are displayed by the Nova Guarita gneiss (0.04 <Eu/Eu* <0.09), X1
quartz-feldspar porphyry (0.35 <Eu/Eu* <0.58) and Jorge granodiorite (0.45 <Eu/Eu* <0.51)

(Fig. 6.7A, 6.7E-F), which indicate that plagioclase would have been extracted from magma during
the fractional crystallization or may have remained as a residual phase during the partial melting.

Primitive mantle-normalized (McDonough & Sun, 1995) trace elements (Fig. 6.10), in all the
investigated samples display conspicuous negative Nb and Ti anomalies and more pronounced K
and Sr negative anomalies, except for Ti (for Nova Guarita gneiss) and Sr (for X1 granodiorite, Pé
Quente tonalite and Jorge granodiorite) where they occur as positive anomalies. Moreover, positive
K, Ba, Pb and Th anomalies can be seen in all units and may be related to some supracrustal
assimilation during the emplacement. According to Wernik (2004), Yang et al., (2008) and
Chadrasekharam et al., (2009), the pronounced Nb, Sr and Ti anomalies, such as low Ta and Y
145
contents, are typically found in I-type granites originated within an arc-like setting. Furthermore,
with fractionation, the negative Ti and Sr anomalies become more pronounced, whereas the
negative Nb anomaly becomes smaller. Additionally, we found that in all lithologies a
systematically impoverishment in incompatible elements from Th-U, which is consistent with I-
type igneous fractionation. Collectively, the REE primitive mantle-normalized and the studied
lithotypes trace elements patterns show a strong correlation with the upper continental crust.
6.5.3 Granitic and tectonic affinities
Based on Whalen et al., (1987) geochemical index that discriminates between A- and S-, I-
type granites, all our lithotypes are characterized by low (Ga/Al)*10 4 ratios (1.66-2.58), low Nb (up
to 16.2 ppm) and Zr (up to 254.4 ppm) contents, which place them into the I-type granites field
(Fig. 11), with similarities between orogenic and fractionated granitoids.
Fig. 6.11. Geochemical discrimination diagrams (Whalen et al., 1987) showing (Ga/Al)*10 4 plotted against
Zr and Nb concentrations for AFGP basement, plutonic and subvolcanic granitic rocks.
Additionally, all the investigated rock groups fit into the sub-alkaline field on the K2O+Na2O
vs. silica diagram (Fig. 6.12). On the SiO2 versus K2O diagram (Le Maitre et al., 1989), the Guarita
gneiss (K2O = 5-5.5 wt.% ), X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (K2O = 4.7-5.1 wt.%), Jorge granodiorite
(K2O = 4.5-4.8 wt.%) and foliated biotite tonalite (K2O = 4-4.6 wt.%) plot into the high-K field,
whereas the X1 granodiorite (K2O = 3-4.1 wt.%) and Pé Quente biotite tonalite (K2O = 2.4-6.1
wt.%) fall into the medium-K field (Fig. 6.12B). In the modified alkali-lime index (Frost et al.,
146
2001) all samples fall into the calcic-alkali field (Fig. 6.12C). Aluminum saturation indices
(A/CNK, molar) range from 0.89 to 1.22, with the Nova Guarita gneiss, foliated tonalite, X1
granodiorite and X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry within the peraluminous field, whereas Pé Quente
tonalite and Jorge granodiorite into the metaluminous to peraluminous field (Fig. 6.12D).
Accorging to the Fe-number (Frost et al., 2001), the foliated tonalite, X1 granodiorite, Pé Quente
tonalite and Jorge granodiorite are magnesian, whereas the Nova Guarita gneiss are ferroan, and the
X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry belongs to the ferroan to magnesian transition (Fig. 6.12E).
Additionally, the narrow aluminum saturation-index (ASI) range together to the wide dispersion of
SiO2 contents (Fig. 6.12F), that reflects a high fractionated crystallization ratio.
In the (La/Yb)N vs. (Yb)N geochemical discrimination diagrams all the investigated
lithologies plot into the adakite field and in the Sr/Y vs. Y diagram, only the foliated tonalite, Pé
Quente tonalite and X1 granodiorite fall into the adakite-signature field, whereas the other rocks
show normal arc magma signatures (Figs. 6.13A-B). However, based on MgO contents (<1 wt.
%), all samples plot outside the adakite field, but within the metabasaltic and eclogite melts area
(Fig. 6.13C). Moreover, these lithotypes show higher K2O/Na2O ratios (0.51-2.19) and lower
Al2O3 contents (11.2-19.9 wt.%) than those reported for traditional adakite rocks, except in the
cases of Pé Quente and X1 granitic rocks that fit into the adakite-field. The Jorge granodiorite and
foliated tonalite, however, show affinities to adakites derived from lower continental crust (Fig.
6.13D).

6.6.1 Granitic basement
Zircon crystals from Nova Guarita gneiss are inclusion free, idiomorphic and range from
prismatic, ovoids to elongated shapes (Fig. 6.16A). The crystals are pale brown and range in size
from 55.7 to 397.06 ?m. Except in rare cases, most of the zircon crystals are relatively dark and
exhibit a poorly developed oscillatory zoning. A few crystals displayed a xenocrystic core and
therefore, were not analyzed. Thirty six spot analyses were performed on 30 zircon crystals, 12 of
which with acceptable 204
Pb (up to 15 wt.%) and U contents. These crystals produced variable Th
(58.88 to 664.89 ppm; mean = 216.47 ppm) and U (189.2 to 6,164.93 ppm; mean = 1,981.86 ppm)
concentrations, such as Th/U ratios (0.06 <Th/U <0.47; mean = 0.15). All these features are
typical of magmatic zircon crystals (Rubatto, 2002) that were homogenized as a solid-state
recrystallization consequence. The 12 analyses points yield concordant age, with 206
Pb/ 238
U
weight average age at 1,980.3 ±8.8 Ma (n = 12; MSWD = 0.77) (Fig. 6.17A).

6.6.2 Granitic host intrusions
Zircon crystals from the Pé Quente tonalite are mostly colorless to pale brown, devoid of
inclusions, and display prismatic to elongated shapes (Fig. 6.16C) with sizes between 72.7 and
372.1 ?m. The CL images indicate that most crystals posses clear and well defined magmatic
oscillatory zoning and show relatively dark rims. We analyzed a total of 22 spots from 20 igneous
zircon crystals (Tab. 6.X), from which seven were discarded due the high 204
Pb values. These
crystals produced low and homogeneous Th (from 25.4 to 262.21ppm; mean = 85.38 ppm) and U
(from 61.27 to 267.64 ppm; mean = 128.61 ppm), which are typical values of zircons from
magmatic origin (Hoskin & Schaltegger, 1993; Rubatto, 2002; Corfu et al., 2003). These zircon
crystals yield concordant U-Pb age, with 206
Pb/ 238
U weight average age at 1,901 ±6.8 Ma (n = 15;
MSWD = 2.4), interpreted as their crystallization age (Fig. 6.17C). We have found only one
inherited zircon in this sample, which yielded a 206
Pb/ 238
U age at 2.030 Ma, and thus, was not
considered on the concordia age.
Zircon crystals from X1 granodiorite are inclusion-free, idiomorphic and range from
prismatic to elongated shapes, with few ovoids (Fig. 6.16D). Their sizes vary from 46.8 to 365.7
?m and are mainly colorless, with a few pale yellow to brown. The CL images indicate that most
crystals possess clear and well defined magmatic oscillatory zoning, and few are relatively dark.
Only one crystal exhibits a xenocrystic core with external overgrowths, but it was not analyzed.
Altogether, 21 spot analyses were performed on 18 zircon crystals (Tab. 6.X). These crystals
revealed low to high Th (53.5 to 4,907.28 ppm; mean = 542.52 ppm) and U (76.54 to 2,115.86
ppm; mean = 403.9 ppm) concentrations, and a concordant U-Pb crystallization age, with
206 Pb/
238 U weight average age at 1,904.4 ±4.6 Ma (n = 13; MSWD = 0.84) (Fig. 6.17D).
Additionally, five crystals yielded a 206
Pb/ 238
U weight average age of 2,064 ±12 Ma (MSWD =
0.93) and were excluded from the age calculation because they were interpreted as inherited
grains.
Zircon crystals from Jorge granodiorite are idiomorphic, range from prismatic to very
elongated shapes and are colorless to pale yellow (Fig. 6.16E). The crystal sizes are between 76.2
and 372.2 ?m. The CL images indicate that most crystals are relatively dark and show well
defined magmatic oscillatory zoning. No xenocrystic core was found within the crystals. Forty
spot analyses were performed on 36 zircon crystals, however, 28 of them were not used for
presenting inconsistent analytical results. The remaining data produced uniform Th (119.09 to
154
509.95 ppm; mean = 290 ppm) and U (81.16 to 328.69 ppm; mean = 200.65 ppm) concentrations,
but variable Th/U ratios (0.72 <Th/U <2.13; mean = 1.51). These crystals yield a concordant
crystallization U-Pb age, with 206
Pb/ 238

1.03) (Fig. 6.17E).
Collectively, the zircon crystals from the granitic host intrusion group exhibit simple
oscillatory zoning and most of them show mostly straight core-rim-boundaries, which may point
to a magmatic origin under quickly grown rims or even fluid under-saturated conditions (Vavra et
al., 1999; Corfu et al., 2003; Flowerdew et al., 2006).
6.6.3 Subvolcanic host granite
Zircon crystals from X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry are elongated to prismatic shapes, with
sizes from 32.5 to 190.5 ?m and with no inclusions. The crystals are mainly brownish, show
oscillatory zoning with low CL response (Fig. 6.16F). However, few of them exhibit a weakely
defined oscillatory zoning. For corresponding a lithotype with a very small zircon concentration,
which was confirmed during the petrography, we carried out only four analyses on four igneous
zircon crystals (Tab. 6.X), which produced variable Th (334.5 <Th <2,107.6 ppm; mean =
1,197.1 ppm) and U (371.6 <U <1,541.4 ppm; mean = 920.4 ppm) contents, besides low to
moderate Th/U ratios (0.67 <Th/U <1.63; mean = 1.29). These zircon crystals yield concordant
U-Pb age, with 206
Pb/ 238
U weight average age of 1,773 ±5.7 Ma (n = 4; MSWD = 1.3) (Fig.
6.17F). Additionally, no older component or even inherited zircon was detected for this rock.
