6 . 8 D I S C U S S I O N S
8.1 Geochemical and isotopic implications for the regional magmatism.
The lithotypes studied in this work vary in composition from tonalite to monzogranite, are
medium to high-K, sub-alkaline, calc-alkaline, peraluminous I-type granites and display
magnesium to ferrous affinities (Figs. 6.11-6.12). Except for the Pé Quente tonalite, that shows
moderate evolved issue, all others exhibit a strongly evolved behavior (Fig. 6.7). On Harker
diagrams the whole dataset shows continuous trends that are typical of fractionated crystallization
(Fig. 6.5).
Our lithologies exhibit very different U-Pb zircon crystallization ages, except for X1 biotite
granodiorite and Pé Quente biotite tonalite, for which the ages are practically the same: respectively
1,904 ±4,6 Ma and 1,901 ±6.8 (Fig. 6.17). Except for a very small silica gap between 71.3 and 72.5
wt.%, the Pé Quente tonalite and X1 granodiorite are usually aligned in a continuous silica trends
(Figs. 6.5, 6.9, 6.12 and 6.14), indicative that they might be comagmatic rocks.
Except for the X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry that exhibits wider range of
Al2O3/(FeO+MgO+TiO2) ratios (from 7.31 to 21.52), all the other samples exhibit more restricted
ratios, which decrease from for the Nova Guarita gneiss (7.46-10.22), to X1 granodiorite (8.56-
12.91), Pé Quente tonalite (5.02-7.2), foliated biotite tonalite (5.29-6.22) and finally to Jorge
granodiorite (3.41-3.55). According to Patiño Douce (1999), I-type granitoids are derived from
partial melting of igneous sources, such as those from typical lower crustal lithologies where
anatexis is a consequence of dehydration of amphibole and mica-rich sources. Melts derived from
an amphibolile-rich source have a more restricted range of Al2O3/(FeO+MgO+TiO2) ratios, but a
wider range of total abundances of Al2O3 + FeO + MgO + TiO2 than melts derived from a mica-
rich source. An amphibole-dominated residue for these rocks is consistent with low TiO2 contents
(0.08 to 0.48 wt.%), low Rb/Sr (0.024 to 4.11) and Nb/Ta ratios (8.75-29.5) (Petford & Atherton,
1996; Foley et al., 2002).
Based on the REE patterns, the results suggest that the igneous fractionation would have been
more effective in the Nova Guarita gneiss and Jorge granodiorite than in the foliated tonalite,
quartz-feldspar porphyry, X1 granodiorite and Pé Quente tonalite, which show lower ?LREE/?HREE
ratios (Fig. 6.8). Moreover, the flat HREE patterns we observed in these rocks further indicate that
amphibole was likely to be the major residual phase during partial melting of the mafic lower crust.
Moreover, the REE patterns also show either low HREE concentration abundances as moderate
159
fractionated pattern that suggest that the garnet may have also been an important phase in the
residuum. This geochemical behavior might be related to the high partition coefficients found in the
accessory mineral phases, such titanite and apatite, wich contribute either in the LREE enrichment
such as in Gd and Tb (Rollison, 2003).
Based on tectonomagmatic discrimination diagrams (Fig. 6.14), we observed from Pé Quente
tonalite to foliated tonalite ? X1 granodiorite ? X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry ? Nova Guarita
gneiss and Jorge granodiorite a well defined trend that can be attributed to evolution of the tectonic
setting, firstly from arc-type granites with generating of most primitives rocks (e.g. Pé Quente
tonalite), toward the post-collisional granites setting with more evolved rocks (e.g. X1 quartz-
feldspar porphyry and Jorge granodiorite). Alternatively, this geochemical trend could either reflect
igneous fractionation and/or supracrustal assimilation.
Taking the adakite-index into account, the Pé Quente and X1 plutonic host rocks seem to be
the closest to the adakitic-signature. Respectively, these rocks show Na2O contents between 4.19-
4.81 wt.% and 4.3-4.89 wt.%, besides comparable Al2O3 (14.44-15.17 wt.% and 15.26-16.43
wt.%), which according to Defant & Drummont (1990), Martin et al., (2005) and Moyen (2009)
are compatible to those usually reported as adakite affinity. On the other hand, these plutonic host
rocks (X1 and Pé Quente, respectively) show extremely low MgO contents (0.25-0.39 wt.% and
0.49-0.78 wt.%; Fig. 6.13C), low #Mg*100 (33.7-40.1 and 37.7-39.4), higher K2O/Na2O ratio
(0.66-0.96 and 0.51-0.72), besides low FeO+MgO+MnO+TiO2 values (from 1.16 to 1.79 and from
2.2 to 3.26 wt.% ) and low Ni (0.8-1.3 and 0.9-2.2) and Cr (below the detection limit of 0.002
wt.% for Cr2O3) contents compared to the regular adakite-signature. In accordance to Defant &
Drummont (1990), Martin et al., (2005) and Moyen (2009) adakite-signature exhibits MgO ~3
wt.%, ~7 wt.% of FeO+MgO+MnO+TiO2 and relatively high Ni and Cr contents (24 and 36 ppm,
respectively) and #Mg*100 of ~50.
Therefore, these plutonic host rocks of granodioritic-tonalitic composition show an adakite-
like signature similar to those assigned as K-adakites (also designed as continental adakites; Gao
et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2007), which are contrasting to the adakitic nature, initially described as
sodic rocks. Moreover, Richards & Kerrich (2007) pointed out that calc-alkaline andesite series
usually do evolve into the adakitic field by fractionated crystallization or FC processes. This
seems to be the case of our “adakite-like” rocks, what was further confirmed by their high
K2O/Na2O rations and low #Mg*100 plus MgO contents. Additionally, their primitive mantle-
160
normalized trace element patterns (Figs. 6.8 and 6.10) are characterized by LREE enrichment and
HREE depletion, besides positive Rb, U, Pb, Sr anomalies and negative Nb, Ta, Ti anomalies,
suggesting a subduction component inheritance in the magma generation process. However, their
metaluminous signature, relatively low ?Nd(t) values of -5.49 to -2.88, positive Sr anomalies (Figs.
6.10, 6.12D and 6.18) and the absence of significant Eu anomalies (Fig. 6.8), are according to
Defant and Drummond (1990), considerably different from those of typical slab-derived adakites
with MORB-like isotopic compositions. These lithogeochemical and isotopic characteristics,
along with the tectonic setting, rule out their generation in a subduction zone by the oceanic slab
partial melting.
Actually, high Sr/Y and La/Yb ratios are usually interpreted as reflecting deep melting. As
the pressure increases, the plagioclase becomes unstable, therefore, releasing Sr and La, whereas
garnet becomes stable and correspond the more important phase that traps Y and Yb. As a result, a
huge increase of these ratios takes place with pressure increment (Moyen, 2009). Thus, the high
Sr/Y and La/Yb ratios and the Sr contents, together with low Y contents obtained to our rocks
imply that the magma was derived from a source at pressures high enough to stabilize garnet ±
amphibole (Martin, 1986), typical of thickened lower crust, approximately 55-65 km thickness
and pressures about 1.7–2 GPa (Petford & Atherton, 1996; Moyen, 2009;Berzina et al., 2014). At
lower depths, the residual phase would be plagioclase-rich and garnet absent, what explains the
lack of Eu/Eu* anomalies. Thus, in this work we prefer to use the adakite-like term to refer to
these rocks that were originated at deep thickened lower crust, instead of “adakite sensu stricto”.
These latter are restricted to subduction environments, more precisely associated to hot
subductions, where a young and hot lithosphere is subducted, or even flat, young and fast
subduction zones that are also believed to produce hot thermal regimes (Defant and Drummond,
1990; Martin, 1999; Moyen, 2009), which is not our case. Therefore, care must be taken in using a
single parameter as a main geochemical identification criteria, such as Y vs. Sr/Y and Yb vs.
La/Yb plots, to distinguish this type of rocks.
The calculated TDM ages for all the investigated rock groups, range from 2.51 to 2.12 Ga
(Fig. 6.18A), indicative that the original magmas were dominantly produced by reworking or
remelting of Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic juvenile source with crustal contribution. The
Neoarchean sources are exclusively observed on the Pé Quente host rocks. In additional, the ?Nd(t)
values for these rocks concentrate between -5.49 and -1.39, suggesting primitive mantle-derived
161
material with small crustal contamination vector or even a mixing between the metasomatized
mantle and crust, as implyed by trace element ratios (Fig. 6.15). The crustal contamination is also
observed by the variable 87
Sr/ 86
Sr(i) ratios (0.79826 to 1.34909) observed individually for each
lithology (Tab. 6.3). The crust component may have derived from contamination by older
basement rocks, further suggested by the presence of inherited zircon crystals of ca. 2 Ga. It is
also observed that the older TDM ages, the more negative are the ?Nd(t) values, suggestive of long
time of crustal reworking since the source extraction. Collectively, there is a younging on TDM
model ages from the Pé Quente (2.36-2.28 Ga), toward the X1 tonalite (2.31-2.26 Ga), Nova
Guarita gneiss (2.28-2.26 Ga), foliated tonalite (2.24-2.17 Ga), Jorge granodiorite (2.19-2.16 Ga),
União do Norte porphyry (2.16-2.13 Ga) and to X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (2.07-2.02 Ga).
Fig. 6.19. Correlation between U-Pb zircon crystallization ages and TDM model ages for the investigated
rock units from the eastern sector of the AFGP.
Furthermore, a large difference between the TDM model ages and the U-Pb zircon
crystallization ages (Fig. 6.19) is noted among the investigated rock groups: 301-287 Ma for the
Nova Guarita gneiss; 267-199 Ma for the foliated biotite tonalite; 466-390 Ma and 381-304 Ma
for the Pé Quente tonalite and monzonite, respectively; 411-364 Ma for the X1 granodiorite, 336-
301 Ma for the Jorge granodiorite; 302-256 Ma for the X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry and 396-357
162
Ma for the União do Norte Porphyry. These differences may point to either long time of source
extraction or a long crustal residence time since the magma extraction to its emplacement.
Therefore, taking into account the whole-rock geochemistry and the Sm-Nd-Sr results, it is
suggested that the basement rocks and the granitic rock groups were all derived from magmas
with long time of extraction from a Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic metasomatized mantle-
derived sources. These magmas might have evolved throughout a combination of fractional
crystallization with a minor crustal contamination vector processes.
8.2 Felsic magmatic events
Based on intrusion relationships, geochemistry and geochronology data, the temporal
evolution of the felsic magmatism in the eastern portion of the Alta Floresta Gold Province has
been constrained. These data reveal that felsic magmatism in this province sector developed at
least into three temporally distinct Paleoproterozoic events, separated apart by approximately 311
Ma: (1) Orosirian; (2) Late Orosirian; and (3) Statherian (Fig. 6.20). The first group corresponds
to the basement rocks (Nova Guarita gneiss and foliated tonalite) with ages centered at 1,980 to
1,970 Ma, which may be correlated to the Cuiú-Cuiú complex (1.98-2.03 Ga; Santos et al., 1997;
Paes de Barros, 2007), (1.98 Ga, this work) together with the Novo Mundo granite (1.95-1.97 Ga;
Paes de Barros, 2007) and the Pé Quente monzonite (1.97 Ga; Miguel-Jr, 2011). The second event
is defined between 1,931 Ma and 1,848 Ma, and is marked by the Aragão granite (1.93 Ga;
Miguel-Jr, 2011), X1 granodiorite (1,904 Ma; this work), Pé Quente tonalite (1,901 Ma; this
work), Nhandu granite (1.88-1.87 Ga; Paes de Barros, 2007), Matupá intrusive suite (1.86-1.89
Ga; Moura, 1998; Silva, 2014), União granodiorite (1.85 Ga; Miguel-Jr, 2011) and Juruena suite
(1.82-1.81 Ga; JICA/MMAJ, 2000). And finally, the last event includes ages tightly constrained in
the range of 1,782 to 1,727 Ma that comprises the Teles Pires intrusive suite (1.79-1.75 Ga;
Santos, 2000; Pinho et al., 2003; Prado et al., 2013) and Colíder suite (~1.78 Ga; Pimentel, 2001;
Silva & Abram, 2008), together with the Peixoto pluton (1.79-1.76 Ga; Paes de Barros, 2007;
Silva, 2014) União do Norte porphyry (1,774 Ma; Miguel-Jr, 2011) and X1 quartz-feldspar
porphyry (1,773 Ma; this work). The last two are included in this study into the Teles Pires and
Colíder suites, respectively.

Within the first magmatic event, the 1,980 ±8.8 U-Pb zircon age, the uniform and
homogeneous TDM age (2.28 to 2.26 Ga) and ?Nd(1,980) values (-2.76 to -2.45) reported to the Nova
Guarita gneiss suggest a Rhyacian source directly extracted from the mantle and emplaced in the
onset of an arc during the Orosirian, which would allow a low crustal contamination vector. The
slightly negative ?Nd(1,980) values and the lithogeochemistry data further indicate that this unit
might have originated from a predominantly juvenile arc setting, or even from a juvenile material
extracted directly from a modified-mantle. Its crystallization age and ?Nd(t) are similar to the Alto
Alegre gneiss (1,984 ±7 Ma; Paes de Barros, 2007). Based on Pb-Pb zircon age of 2,816±4 Ma
obtained to the Gavião gneiss, Paes de Barros (2007) correlatates the Alto Alegre gneiss to the
Xingu Complex (2,859 ±2 Ma and 2,860 ± 2 Ma; Machado et al., 1991), from the Tapajós
Province (SW Pará State). However, the Alto Alegre gneiss shows an older TDM age (~2.65 Ga),
suggesting an Archean source. Nevertheless, gneisses of granitic composition dated at 1,992 ±7
Ma (SHRIMP U-Pb zircon age) are reported by Souza et al. (2005), and correlated to the Cuiú-
Cuiú Complex in the Tapajós Province. Ages about 1.98-1.99 Ga, within the error range, are
compatible to the SHRIMP U-Pb zircon ages of 2,005 ±7 published by Santos et al., (1997) for the
Cuiú-Cuiú Complex. Therefore, given the lack of inherited zircon crystals older than 2.1 Ga in the
Nova Guarita gneiss, we propose to abandon the Xingu Complex term adopted by Paes de Barros
(2007) for the province basement. This conclusion is further supported by the absence of gneiss
with ages older than 1,992 ±7 Ma in the province. Additionally, Xingu Complex rocks are mainly
composed of trondhjemitic, migmatites, amphibolites and gneisses of tonalitic compositions dated
at 2,859 ±2 Ma and 2,860 ± 2 Ma (U-Pb zircon age; Machado et al., 1991). Moreover, the Pb-Pb
zircon age of 2,816±4 Ma obtained to the Gavião gneiss could represent inherited zircons derived
from reworking of Archean crust, or alternatively, some inherited zircon from the Bacaeri-Mogno
Complex (2.24 Ga; Sm-Nd isochron; Pimentel, 2001).
The 1,978 ±8.1 crystallization age, the TDM model ages (2.17 to 2.24) and the uniform
?Nd(1,978) values (-1.99 to -0.97) reported for the foliated tonalite, suggest a slightly younger
magmatic event, originated in the Rhyacian, but emplaced in the Orosirian. The slightly negative
165
?Nd(1,978) values together with the geochemistry data suggest a minor crustal contamination
component, which could be possible in rocks formed within a juvenile arc setting with poorly-
developed continental crust. Thus, giving their crystallization age and deformation, the Nova
Guarita gneiss and the foliated tonalite are, in this study, broadly and respectively correlated to the
Cuiú-Cuiú Complex and to the calc-alkaline, I-type, arc-related granitic rocks of the Creporizão
suite (1,997 ±3 to 1,957 ±6 Ma; Vasquez et al., 2000; Klein et al., 2000), both from the
neighbouring Tapajós Gold Province. The former comprises its basement, whereas the latter
corresponds to the earliest granitic intrusions. Additionally, regardless of the correlation adopted,
these data suggest cogenetic but not comagmatic gneissic basement to the province.
The U-Pb zircon ages, geochemical and isotopic data indicate that the Pé Quente tonalite
and X1 granodiorite, representatives of the secong granitic rock group, are coeval and
comagmatic. Due to their similarities, it is proposed the term Guarantã granite to refer to these
host rocks that vary in composition from tonalite to granodiorite. This term is named after
Guarantã do Norte city, since the only outcrop known and described for this unit crops out
surrounding the X1 deposit, placed at this city. Therefore, its crystallization ages vary from 1,904
±4.6 Ma to 1,901 ±6.8 Ma, which are very similar (with the uncertainties) to those reported to
Matupá Intrusive suite (1,894 ±6 to1,869 ±12 Ma; Moura, 1998; JICA/MMAJ, 2000; Silva, 2014)
and Nhandu granite (1,889 ±17 to 1,879 ±5.5 Ma; Silva & Abram, 2008).
Moreover, it could be identified and discussed two periods of felsic magmatism
emplacement in the Pé Quente deposit: (1) A first one less evolved and fractionated, mainly
composed of monzonite dated at 1,979 Ma (Miguel-Jr, 2011) and; (2) A last one, intrusive into the
monzonite and characterized by tonalite plutons dated at 1.9 Ga. However, precaution must be
taken about the dubious crystallization age assigned to Pé Quente monzonite (1,979 ±31 Ma;
Miguel-Jr, 2011), as it corresponds to an upper intercept age (discordant age) based only on three
zircon crystals, one of them, extremely discordant. This age could represent inherited zircon
crystals either from the basement or even from the foliated tonalite, and consequently, it may not
represent the monzonite crystallization age. The host Pé Quente monzonite crosscuts the foliated
tonalite which, in turn, shows a similar age (1,977±8 Ma) to that obtained to the monzonite. Thus,
inherited zircon crystals from the foliated tonalite should be the most consistent conclusion for the
1,979 Ma monzonite age reported by Miguel-Jr (2011).
166
The later magmatic event is mostly represented by the emplacement of porphyries and
subvolcanic bodies in a syn-collisional to within-plate environment. The 1,773 ±5.7 Ma obtained
for the X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry is consistent and in good agreement (within the error range)
with the arc-like Colíder suite age that ranges from 1,786 ±17 to 1,781 ±8 Ma. Considering the
volcanic arc-type affinity of the X1 porphyry, this correlation is futher confirmed. Thus, it is
proposed that the magmatic event related to Colíder suite is slightly older than originally believed.
Additionally, the União do Norte Porphyry represents a post-collisional alkaline A-type granite
emplaced at 1,774 ±7.5 Ma, belonging to the Teles Pires intrusive suite (Miguel-Jr, 2011; Assis et
al., 2012) (Fig. 6.20).
8.3 Implications for tectonic regime
Currently, three main tectonic models have been used by different authors to explain the
felsic plutonic-volcanic events that have taken place in the Amazon Craton: (1) Within-plate
magmatism model (Neder et al., 2002); (2) Post-collisional extensional magmatism model
(Lamarão et al., 2002; Barros et al., 2009; Assis, 2011; Assis et al., 2012); and (3) Accretionary
arc magmatism model (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos, 2000; Assis, 2011). We propose in
this work that the plutonic and volcanic sequences of the eastern sector of the AFGP have been
generated from magmatism triggered by subduction in a volcanic arc setting. This interpretation is
based on the following arguments: (1) the presence of biotite, apatite, titanite and magnetite as
accessory phases that typify felsic, hydrated and oxidized I-type magmas (White & Chappell,
1974; White & Chappell, 1977; Cobbing, 2000; Chappell & White, 2001); (2) the calc-alkaline,
medium to high-K, ferrous and meta- to peraluminous affinity; (3) the well-defined major and
trace elements trend relative to silica increment that are generally related to I-type granites, which
for having a mantle source display a small crustal assimilation vector that consequently reflects
homogeneity and strong correlations on the whole-rock geochemistry (White & Chappell, 1974;
Cobbing, 2000; Chappell & White, 2001); (4) the trace element signatures are related to volcanic-
arc magmatism, that corresponds to typical melts produced from subduction-modified sources; (5)
?Nd(t) values (-5.49 to -0.975) and TDM model ages (2.36 to 2.02 Ga) provide strong argument for
mantle-derived magmas emplaced into a juvenile crust, with mix between reworked arc-related
material; (7) very small proportion of zircon crystals that contain inherited cores older than 2.03-
2.06 Ga, that according to Tafti et al., (2009) suggest a predominantly origin within a juvenile arc
167
setting, possibly near to the edge of older terrains; (8) predominance of intermediate rocks from
tonalite to granodiorite composition; and the (9) moderate fractionated REE patterns, moderate to
absent Eu/Eu* negative anomalies that are usually produced from fractionated mantle-derived
magmas.
Within this context, there is a significant consensus that the most granitic rocks in the
province were build up during several magmatic arcs over the Paleo and Mesoproterozoic
collision (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Cordani & Teixeira, 2007; Souza et al., 2005; Silva &
Abram, 2008). Taking these arguments into account, these events can be categorized into three
tectono-magmatic events according to the accretion of volcanic arcs model (Fig. 6.21).
Stage I: Cuiú-Cuiú magmatic arc (2.1 to 1.95 Ga)
The first magmatic stage is related to the development of the Cuiú-Cuiú volcanic arc, with
production of large magmatic-volcanic activity similar to those described within modern volcanic
arcs (Souza et al., 2005). This stage may have generated calc-alkaline, oxidized I-type granitic
magmas that interacted with juvenile crust, here represented by the Orosirian granitic basement,
foliated granitoids and old granites (first magmatic event; Fig. 6.21A). However, their deformation
gradient may reflect a later stage of the tectonic setting (toward the post-collisional), which is
further confirmed by the high Rb-Ta-Yb concentrations and the negative ?Nd(t) values. Within this
scenario, a granitic magma would have emplaced into a deeper crustal level, and consequently,
metamorphosed into higher P-T conditions, with later gneiss formation. The foliated tonalite may
represent a hydrated and oxidized I-type felsic magma emplaced into a slightly shallower crust,
where the P-T conditions would not have been high enough to a compositional banding formation.
Moreover, the unmetamorphosed oldest granitic plutons studied in the province, like Pé Quente
monzonite (1.97 Ga(?); ?Nd(t) = -2.38 to -2.88; TDM age = 2.51-2.41 Ga; Assis, 2011; Miguel-Jr,
2011) and Novo Mundo granite (1.96-1.96 Ga; ?Nd(t) = -7.62 to -4.58; TDM age = 2.76-2.55 Ga;
Paes de Barros, 2007; Abreu, 2004), also would have been formed in this platform, but in a later
stage. If taken together, these units could represent a geodynamic evolution since a volcanic arcs
platform, with crystallization of granitic (and its metamorphism into gneiss) and tonalite rocks, to
a more evolved setting (toward the post-collisional onset), with emplacement of Pé Quente
monzonite followed by Novo Mundo granite, which would reflect its lower ?Nd(t) and more
evolved petrographic and geochemical signatures.

Alternatively, this stage could also be related to the Ventuari-Tapajós volcanic arc
development (1.95 to 1.8 Ga), within the Tassinari & Macambira (1999) model, also with
petrotectonic and geochemical signature similar to modern volcanic arcs.
Stage II: Early Juruena magmatic arc (1.9 to 1.8 Ga)
This stage, related to the Juruena magmatic arc construction, might have been responsible
for the major event of crustal growth within the province, with a very large amount of plutonic and
volcanic sequences production, and related to the second magmatic event (Fig. 6.21B). This
second stage is represented by the the emplacement of Guarantã granit (~1,9 Ga), Nhandu granite
(1,889-1,879 Ma; Paes de Barros), Matupá suite (1,894 ±6 to1,869 ±12 Ma; Moura, 1998;
JICA/MMAJ, 2000; Silva, 2014), Paranaíta suite (1,816 to 1,793 Ma; Santos, 2000; Souza et al.,
2005; Silva & Abram, 2008) and Juruena suite (1,823 ±35 to 1,817 ±17 Ma; JICA/MMAJ, 2000),
also similar to modern volcanic arcs. Over again, it is associated to the Paleoproterozoic calc-
alkaline, oxidized I-type granitic magmas origins that would have interacted with juvenile crust
and, consequently, represented by the Guarantã granite and the Jorge granodiorite emplacement.
Taken those units collectively, they again represent the tectonic setting evolution, with production
of a more primitive magmatism in a volcanic arc onset, illustrated by Guarantã granite (tonalite-
granodiorite composition), toward a more stable platform, with generation of more evolved felsic
magmas with higher assimilation/contamination by crustal rocks, such as Matupá and Paranaíta
granites.
On the other hand, according to the model proposed by Tassinari & Macambira (1999), this
stage could alternatively be related to the construction of the Rio Negro-Juruena arc (1.8 to 1.55
Ga), also similar to modern volcanic arcs (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Cordani & Teixeira,
2007). However, the oldest granitic plutons related to our second magmatic event, like Guarantã
and Nhandu granites (1.9-1.84 Ga), would be associated to the Ventuari-Tapajós (1.95-1.8 Ga)
magmatic activity, whereas the Paranaíta and Matupá suites (1.79-1.87 Ga) would be restricted to
the Rio Negro-Juruena arc, a younger island arc. Our new U-Pb zircon ages are the first
geochronological constraints into the AFGP regarding to granitic systems older than Matupá
Intrusive suite (1,872 ±12 Ma; Moura, 1998) that are not belonging to the regional basement. This
perspective brings an important tectonic constrains about the limit between the Ventuari-Tapajós
and Rio Negro-Juruena provinces, and consequently, of the AFGP. Therefore, the oldest granitic
170
plutons found within the province easternmost portion might not belong to the Rio Negro-Juruena
province, but to the Ventuari-Tapajós. Consequently, the Cachimbo graben does not record
accurately the boundary between the Tapajós (Almeida et al., 1981; Tassinari & Macambira,
1999) and Alta Floresta provinces, which would be slightly to the southwest. In this case, there
would be an elongation of the Tapajós Province under the graben toward its southwest edge.
Another possibility also plausible would be that these older granitic plutons, together with the
granitic basement, may correspond to a narrow suture zone between the Ventuari-Tapajós and Rio
Negro-Juruena provinces.
Stage III: Post-collisional Juruena magmatic arc setting (1.78 to 1.75 Ga)
This last magmatic-volcanic episode would be related to the generation of the porphyries
and volcanic to subvolcanic units, in a more stable platform, from a post-collisional toward a
within-plate setting, designed in this work as the Statherian later magmatic event (Fig. 6.21C).
During this period, I-type evolved felsic magmatism with continental affinity plus anorogenic
magmas were produced, and illustrated by the Colíder (~1.78 Ga) and Teles Pires (1.79-1.75 Ga)
suites. Nevertheless, this episode would be further related to the generation of alkaline granitic
magmas, exemplified for the Teles Pires intrusive suite. In a post-collisional setting, the major
crustal peak thickening usually began in an extension phase, as a result of a thickened continental
crust gravitational instability, which led to the asthenosphere uplift and melting it, with subsequent
emplacement of mantle-derived magmas into the continental crust base. According to Harris et al.,
(1986) and Liégeois (1998), if within this context, the continental crust is relatively thin, occurs
the production and emplacement of basaltic magma, however, if the crust is thicker, the heat flow
generated by the rise of the asthenosphere, which is resulted from the continental crust thinning,
triggering its lower portion melting, with consequent formation of alkaline A-type granite
magmas.Therefore, this latter process may have been the responsible for the back-arc onset
construction and, consequently, its instability and extension. As a result, the alkaline granitic
magmas formation would have been triggered, and therefore, followed by the A2-type granite
formation (Eby, 1992), such as Teles Pires suite and União do Norte porphyry.Additionally, this
argument is further confirmed by the presence of alkaline felsic rocks coeval to mafic rocks,
described by Barros et al., (2009) that interpret it as a result of a peridotitic mantle melting
modified by lithospheric subduction within a post-collision extension.
171
Alternatively, this third magmatic event could have occurred during the post-collisional
period associated with the Rio Negro-Juruena event after its amalgamation to the Ventuari-
Tapajós province, according the model designed by Tassinari & Macambira (1999).
C o n cl u s i o n s
We believe we can state the following conclusions based on the data presented:
(1) Three granitoids broad groups are distinguished based on mapping, petrography and
geochronology: (a) Granitic basement composed of Nova Guarita gneiss (1,980 ±8.8 Ma) and
foliated tonalite (1,978 ±8.1 Ma); (b) Granitic host rocks: X1 granodiorite (1,904 ±4.6 Ma), Pé
Quente tonalite (1,901 ±6.8 Ma) and Jorge granodiorite (1,863 ±4.8 Ma); and (c) Porphyries and
subvolcanic host rocks: X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (1,773 ±5.7 Ma).
(2) These lithologies are hydrated, oxidized, calc-alkaline, medium to high-K, ferrous and
meta- to peraluminous I-type granitoids that may have derived from partial melting of lower
crustal sources, emplaced into a juvenile crust and with geochemical characteristics of volcanic
arcs.
(3) The Pé Quente tonalite and X1 granodiorite, for having the same crystallization ages
and geochemical behavior, are grouped into a new local unit, here designated as Guarantã granite.
(4) Although the Guarantã granite displays an adakite-like signature, contrasting with the
other lithotypes, this adakitic nature might reflect its high level of crustal origin (garnet-rich and
plagioclase-poor source), possibly from the deep thickened lower crust, instead of the hot thermal
adakitic origin.
(5) The whole dataset table suggests magmas with a Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic source
from a metasomatized mantle (mantle-derived), with long time of mantle extraction and that might
have evolved throughout a fractional crystallization with a lesser contamination/assimilation
vector processes combination.
(6) The new SHRIMP U-Pb zircon ages allow us to categorize the plutonic-volcanic rocks
formation within the province easternmost segment into three main magmatic stages: (a) Orosirian
granitic basement and Old granites; (b) Late Orosirian granitic host rocks; and (c) Statherian
porphyries and subvolcanics rocks.
(7) These magmatic stages can be respectively associated to the tectono-magmatic events
based on a volcanic arc model: (Stage I): Cuiú-Cuiú magmatic arc, from 2.1 to 1.95 Ga; (Stage II):
172
Early Juruena magmatic arc, between 1.9 and 1.8 Ga; and finally the (Stage III): Post-collisional
Juruena magmatic arc setting, from 1.78 to 1.75 Ga.

ABSTRACT
The Alta Floresta Gold Province, which is located in the southern portion of the Amazon Craton,
represents a tectonic unit primarily composed of plutono-volcanic sequences generated in a continental arc
during the Paleoproterozoic. Particularly in its easternmost segment, several granite-hosted gold-rich
deposits are hosted by oxidized I-type, calc-alkaline to sub-alkaline, medium to high K, metaluminous to
peraluminous emplaced into a volcanic arc setting. Pé Quente (Pé Quente Suite; 1.97-1.9 Ga), Luizão
(Novo Mundo pluton; 1.97-1.96 Ga) and X1 (Guarantã granite; 1.9 Ga) deposits are the main
representative and more systematically studied deposits in the province, in which the gold mineralization
occurs minly disseminated or as vein-type. Within the ore zones of the Luizão and X1 deposits, the
granitic rocks are strongly altered to sericite/muscovite+chlorite+quartz (phyllic altearation), and contain
abundant pyrite with variable concentrations of chalcopyrite+hematite, together with minor barite, galena
and Bi-Te-bearing phases. These zones are enveloped by pervasive potassic alteration with orthoclase +
microcline ± hematite. Although these alteration types are also seen at the Pé Quente deposit, its gold-
sulfide association is related both to earlier sodic and phyllic alterations. These deposits, therefore, may be
generally classified as granite-hosted magmatic-hydrothermal systems and bear similarities in some
aspects to gold-only, Cu-poor porphyry systems. In this paper it is reported for the first time Re-Os pyrite
and molybdenite ages for the primary gold-mineralization of the AFGP, based on these three most
important disseminated granite-hosted gold deposits. The Re-Os pyrite ages for the Pé Quente deposit vary
from 1,792 ±9 Ma to 1,784 ±11 Ma, whereas those for Luizão deposit are between 1,790 ±9 Ma and 1,782
±9 Ma. The Re-Os molybdenite ages for X1 deposit range from 1,787 ±7 Ma to 1,785 ±7 Ma. These ages
constrain a single gold metallogenetic event of approximately 10 Ma in the Statherian and allow to
correlate the ore-forming processes with the post-collisional felsic magmatism of the Juruena arc, possibly
associated with the emplacement of the Colíder and Teles Pires suítes. This conclusion is opposite to the
current view that has proposed purely on geological relationships three stages for the AFGP gold
metallogeny: (i) 1.98-1.95 Ga (e.g., Luizão and Pé Quente deposits); (ii) 1.87-1.85 Ga (X1 deposit) and
(iii) 1.77-1.79 Ga (e.g. Bigode and Francisco deposits). These new Re-Os pyrite and molybdenite ages
open new perspectives for gold exploration in the province as widespread plutonic-volcanic suítes now
known as those temporally related to the main gold event, such as the Colider suite, now may become
prime targets.
Keywords: Alta Floresta Gold Province, sulfide Re-Os age, gold metallogeny timing, magmatic
activity, tectonic setting.
182
7 . 1 I N T R O D U C T I O N
A great number of small size (<5 t) and high grade granite-hosted gold and gold-base metal
deposits have been discovered and many exploited in the Alta Floresta Gold Province (AFGP),
southern portion of the Amazon Craton (Brazil), over the last 30 years (Paes de Barros, 2007).
These primary deposits have been historically exploited by artisanal prospectors (garimpeiros)
mainly in the eastern segment of this province, where they form a NW-SE-striking belt, informally
denominated Peru-Trairão belt. The province, also referred to as Juruena-Teles Pires Gold
Province, (Silva & Abram 2008) is formed primarily of Paleoproterozoic plutonic-volcanic
sequences generated in volcanic arcs settings that extends for over 500 km NW-SE.
Based on mode of occurrence, ore mineral paragenesis and geochemical signature, the
primary gold mineralizations in the AFGP may be subdivided into two groups: (1) disseminated
(e.g., Luizão, Dionissio, Basílio, Serrinha, Juruena, X1 and Pé Quente deposits) and structurally-
controlled vein-type (e.g., Paraíba, Buriti and Pezão deposits) Au ± Cu (Bi, Te, Ag, Mo) deposits,
represented dominantly by pyrite and variable concentrations of chalcopyrite (Moura, 1998;
Abreu, 2004; Moura et al., 2006; Paes de Barros, 2007; Assis, 2011; Rodrigues, 2012; Stabile-Jr,
2012; Trevisan, 2012; Acevedo, 2014); and (2) structurally-controlled vein-type Au + Zn + Pb ±
Cu (e.g., Franscisco, Bigode and Luiz deposits), with pyrite and significant concentrations of
sphalerite, galena and minor digenite and chalcopyrite (Assis, 2011). The great majority of these
gold deposits are hosted by relatively oxidized I-type, calc-alkaline to alkaline, medium to high K,
metaluminous to slightly peraluminous granitic rocks (tonalite-granodiorite to syenogranite) and
more subordinately in volcanic/volcaniclastic sequences (Paes de Barros 2007; Assis 2011;
Ramos, 2011).
On the basis of this close spatial relationships and zircon U-Pb ages for the host granitic
rocks, previous works on these deposits have linked the ore-forming processes temporally to arc-
related felsic magmatism and, as a consequence, constrained the relative timing of gold
mineralization in the province within at least three main periods: (1) 1,98 – 1,95 Ga (e.g., Luizão,
Edú and Pé Quente deposits; Paes de Barros 2007; Miguel-Jr 2011); (2) 1,87 – 1,85 Ga (e.g.,
Serrinha deposit; Moura, 1998; Moura et al., 2006), and; (3) 1,77 – 1,75 Ga (e.g., Francisco
deposit; Assis, 2011). However, no attempt to date the gold-sulfide mineralization has been made
in order to substantiate this multiple gold event hipothesis for the AFGP. Therefore, the real
temporal relationship between the host plutonic felsic systems and the emplacement of barren and
183
mineralized granitic units remain unknown. An important implication to resolving the absolute
timing of gold mineralization is to allow a better assessment of the economic potential of specific
granitic intrusions of the province and to the development of genetic models to guide exploration.
Within this scenario, this work reports the first Re-Os pyrite and molybdenite ages for the
primary gold mineralization of the AFGP, based on three of its major disseminated granite-hosted
gold deposits, Pé Quente, Luizão and X1. These data are then compared to the U-Pb zircon
crystallization ages and lithogeochemical data available for the host granitic rocks in order to
assess genetic links with felsic magmatism that took place in the province, and consequently, fit
them into a especifica tectonic setting.
7 . 2 GE O L O G I C A L S E T T I N G
The Alta Floresta Gold Province (AFGP) lies in the southern part of the Amazon Craton, a
crustal segment stabilized at circa 1.0 Ga and divided into several predominantly NW-SE-oriented
tectonic or geochronologic provinces (Almeida, 1978; Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et al.,
2000; Cordani & Teixeira, 2007), and surrounded by Tucavaca (Bolivia), Araguaia-Cuiabá
(Brazil) and Tocantins (Brazil) orogenic belts (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999,2004). This province
has also been named as Juruena-Teles Pires Gold Province (Silva & Abram, 2008), Alta Floresta
Domain (Santos et al., 2001) or even as Alta Floresta Mineral Province (Souza et al., 2005). The
AFGP is located between the Ventuari-Tapajós (1.95-1.8 Ga) and Rio Negro-Juruena (1.8-1.55
Ga) geochronological provinces according to the model of Tassinari & Macambira (1999), or
between the Tapajós-Parima (2.1-1.87 Ga) and Rondônia-Juruena (1.82-1.54 Ga) provinces, if the
model of Santos et al. (2000) is considered (Fig. 7.1). The Ventuari-Tapajós province comprises
mainly syn- to post-collisional calc-alkaline granitoids, whereas the Rio Negro-Juruena province
is dominated by syn- to post-collisional calc-alkaline and alkaline granitoids, with local remnants
of folded and metamorphosed sedimentary sequences (Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et
al., 2000). Collectively, these provinces are posteriorly covered by extensive Cenozoic
sedimentation.
Regardless the adopted model, these provinces are interpreted as an ocean-continent-type
orogeny (plutonic-volcanic sequences) with shallow northwest-southeast dipping subduction,
accreted to the Archean Central Amazonian province during the Paleoproterozoic (ca. 2.05 to 1.88
Ga; Tassinari & Macambira, 1999; Santos et al., 2004; Cordani & Teixeira, 2007).
184
Within the province, the basement is from Orosirian, rarely outcrops and consists of tonalitic
to granitic gneiss and migmatite, both intruded by calc-alkaline foliated granitic rocks that vary in
composition from monzogranite to tonalite (Paes de Barros, 2007). U-Pb SHRIMP zircon ages for
the tonalitic gneiss lie between 1,992 ±7 Ma (Souza et al., 2005) and 1,984 ±7 Ma (Paes de
Barros, 2007), similar to those obtained for the Cuiú-Cuiú Complex (ca. 2,0 Ga) in the
neighbouring of Tapajós Province (Santos et al., 1997). Additionally, Paes de Barros (2007) dated
granitic to tonalitic gneiss rocks from the basement (single zircon Pb-evaporation) and reported
ages at 2,816 ±4 Ma, suggesting a heterogeneous basement with fragments of Archean crust.
Fig. 7.1. Location of the tectonic-geochronological provinces of the Amazon Craton according to the
models of (A) Santos et al. (2006) and (B) Tassinari & Macambira (1999). The yellow grid refers to the
regional geological mapping project of the Alta Floresta Gold Province (Souza et al., 2005).
185
In the easternmost portion of the province, the oldest and unmetamorphosed arc-type granitic
plutons crosscut the basement, are from he late Orosirian and include the Pé Quente (1.97 Ga;
Assis, 2011; Miguel-Jr, 2011), Novo Mundo (1.96 Ga; Paes de Barros, 2007), Flor da Mata and
Aragão (1.93 Ga; Ramos, 2011; Miguel-Jr, 2011). Except for the Flor da Mata granite, these
granitic plutons are host to disseminated or vein-type gold mineralizations. Younger plutonic
units, from Sthaterian, and intrusive into the previous granitic plutons are represented by the
Nhandu granite (1.87 Ga; Silva & Abram, 2008), Matupá Intrusive suite (1.87 Ga; Moura, 1998;
Souza et al., 2005; Assis et al., submitted) and Colíder suite (1.73 to 1.78 Ga; JICA/MMAJ, 2000;
Silva & Abram, 2008; Pimentel, 2001) (Fig. 7.2). The latest magmatic event within the province is
marked by the post-collisional and anorogenic felsic plutono-volcanic units of the Teles Pires
Intrusive suite (1.78 Ga; Silva & Abram, 2008).
Collectively, all these granitic units show affinities to oxidized I-type, calc-alkaline, medium
to high K, magnesium, metaluminous to slightly peraluminous granitic rocks originated in a
volcanic arc setting, except for the Teles Pires suite that corresponds to post-collisional and
anorogenic felsic magmatism (Moura, 1998; Santos et al., 2005; Paes de Barros, 2007; Silva &
Abram, 2008; Assis et al., 2014). Moreover, they could associated to three tectono-magmatic
events based on a volcanic arcs model: (1) (Stage I): Cuiú-Cuiú magmatic arc, from 2.1 to 1.95
Ga; (Stage II): Early Juruena magmatic arc, between 1.9 and 1.8 Ga; and finally the (Stage III):
Post-collisional Juruena magmatic arc setting, from 1.78 to 1.75 Ga.
Overlying all the previous sequences occur Mesoproterozoic pull-apart, maybe strike slip-
type, sedimentary basins defined as Caiabis group and Dardanelos Formation (Moreton &
Martins, 2005; Souza et al., 2005), which correspond, respectively, to the north and south limites
of the province. A summary of the major stratigraphic units, geochronology and tectonic setting of
the AFGP is given in Fig. 7.2 and Table 7.1.

investigated samples were collected from drill-holes that intercepted the main orebodies in each

7.3.2 Re-Os method
The total Re and 187
Os concentrations of six aliquots of pyrite and two of molybdenite were
performed at Radiogenic Isotope Facility, at University of Alberta (Canada). Petrographic studies
on polished thin-sections did not reveal intergrowths or signs of alteration affecting well-formed,
euhedral to sub-anhedral pyrite and molybdenite crystals. Samples were crushed, separated and
194
sieved (roughly at first a later more finely; 40-60 mesh) to obtain monomineralic pyrite and
molybdenite crystals with a purity >99%. The free-inclusions molybdenite and pyrite were
handpicked under a binocular microscope in order to remove impurities of the concentrates.
Metal-free crushing followed by gravity and magnetic concentration methods was used to obtain a
pyrite and molybdenite mineral separate. Samples were measured on a negative thermal ionization
mass spectrometer (NTIMS; Creaser et al., 1991), and the methods used for molybdenite and
pyrite analysis are described in detail by Selby & Creaser (2004) and Markey et al. (2007). The
187 Re and
187 Os concentrations in up to 0.4 g of molybdenite and pyrite aliquots were determined
by isotope dilution mass spectrometry using Carius-tube, solvent extraction, anion
chromatography and negative thermal ionization mass spectrometry techniques. A mixed double
spike containing known amounts of isotopically enriched 185
Re, 190
Os and 188
Os analysis is used.
Isotopic analysis is made using a ThermoScientific Triton mass spectrometer by Faraday collector.
Total procedural blanks for Re and Os are less than<3 picograms and 2 picograms, respectively,
which are insignificant for the Re and Os concentrations in molybdenite and pyrite. The Chinese
molybdenite powder HLP-5 (Markey et al., 1998), is analyzed as a standard. For this control
sample over a period of two years, an average Re-Os date of 221.56 ±0.40 Ma (1SD uncertainty,
n=10) is obtained. This Re-Os age date is identical to that reported by Markey et al. (1998) of
221.0 ±1.0 Ma. The age uncertainty is quoted at 2? level, and includes all known analytical
uncertainty, comprising uncertainty in the decay constant of 187
Re. 95% of confidence level is
reported to all ages obtained.
7.4 GEOLOGY OF THE INVESTIGATED GRANITE-HOSTED GOLD DEPOSITS
7.4.1 Pé Quente deposit
The Pé Quente gold deposit (Assis, 2011) comprises several orebodies hosted by a set of
oxidized I-type fine to medium-grained quartz monzodiorite, leucomonzonite, albitite, biotite
tonalite and crosscutting aplite-like granitic rocks (Figs. 7.3 and 7.4A-B). These rocks show
geochemical affinities to calc-alkaline, medium K, meta- to peraluminous and magnesium granitic
rocks originated in the onset of volcanic arcs. U-Pb zircon ages for the monzonite and biotite
tonalite provided, respectively, crystallization ages of 1,979 ±31 Ma (LA-ICP-MS) and 1,901 ±6.8
Ma (LA-ICP-MS; Miguel-Jr, 2011; Assis et al., submitted). Moreover, the monzonite exhibits
TDM(t) that vary from 2.51 to 2.41 Ga and ?Nd(t) between -2.88 and -3.38, whereas the biotite
195
tonalite shows the same TDM ages (2.5 to 2.41 Ga), but lower ?Nd(t) values (from -5.13 to -4.45),
indicative of Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic juvenile source with crustal contribution (Assis et
al., submitted).

The surrounding rocks of the Pé Quente suite correspond to a series of oxidized I-type
intrusions with compositions varying from tonalite to monzogranite and supposedly correlated to
the Matupá intrusive suite (1.86 to 1.87 Ga; Moura, 1998; Assis et al., 2014).
The hydrothermal alteration sequence associated with the Pé Quente gold mineralization is
represented by: (i) strong and pervasive sodic alteration with albite + quartz + coarse to fine-
grained sulfide (Fig. 7.4C); (ii) pervasive potassic alteration with orthoclase and microcline (Fig.
7.4D); (iii) pervasive to vein-type phyllic alteration with coarse-grained muscovite + quartz +
sulfide paragenesis (Fig. 7.4E); (iv) pervasive and interstitial carbonate alteration with fine to
coarse-grained calcite; (v) silicification and quartz infill commonly accompanied by breccias and
comb-texture quartz veins; (vi) subordinated Mg-rich chlorite; (vii) quartz + albite ± sulfide
196
veinlets; and (viii) later propylitic alteration with epidote + chlorite + tremolite + clinozoisite +
apatite + rutile + pyrite ± titanite ± quartz ± calcite ± actinolite ± prehnite ± chalcopyrite mineral
assemblage (Fig. 7.4F).

Strongly albite-altered monzonite with disseminated and crosscutting coarse-grained pyrite-rich veinlets;

The ore zones comprise pyrite + barite ± hematite ± chalcopyrite ± galena, with very
subordinately wulfenite (PbMoO4), monazite, tivanite [V 3+
TiO3(OH)] and Bi-Te-rich phases
usually as small inclusions within pyrite grains. Gold generally occurs as small inclusions (up to
185 ?m) within pyrite (Fig. 4), with Ag concentrations that range from 14.2 to 46.3wt%. The main
ore zone is both disseminated as vein-type into the phyllic alteration within the biotite tonalite.
197
However, ore-shots are also found disseminated into the pervasive sodic alteration that overprints
quartz monzodiorites and leucomonzonites, such as later quartz + albite veinlets.
7.4.2 Luizão deposit
The Luizão deposit (Abreu, 2004; Paes de Barros, 2007) is hosted by the Novo Mundo
granite, which consists of equigranular leuco-syenogranite and subordinately of monzogranite,
quartz-monzonite and monzonite (Figs. 7.5 and 7.6A). The Novo Mundo granite is relatively
oxidized (magnetite-bearing), calc-alkaline, medium to high potassium, magnesium,
metaluminous to slightly peraluminous and with affinity with volcanic-arc granites (I-type
granite). Single zircon Pb-Pb systematics yielded crystallization ages ranging from 1,970 ±3 Ma
(monzogranite) to 1,964 ±1 Ma (syenogranite), with TDM = 2.5-2.55 Ga and ?Nd(t) from -7.6 to -
3.5, suggesting Archean source with influence of crustal components during emplacement (Paes
de Barros, 2007).
Fig. 7.5. Geological map of the Luizão deposit (Paes de Barros, 2007).
At the deposit scale, the Novo Mundo granite was overprinted by the following
hydrothermal alteration sequence: (1) incipient sodic alteration with albite and quartz; followed by
(2) a strong and pervasive potassic alteration with microcline ± hematite (Fig. 7.6B); (3) a
198
pervasive phyllic alteration with sericite and/or coarse-grained and fibrous radial muscovite +
quartz + Fe-rich chlorite + sulfides, related to the ore zones (Figs. 7.6C-E); and subsequently
replaced by (4) veinlets with epidote, apatite and Ca-Mg-rich carbonate. Later calcite-rich veins
crosscut all the previously hydrothermal styles. The orebodies are discontinuous and configure
rhombohedral blocks delimited and fragmented by narrow fractures zones with phyllic
hydrothermal halos. The mineralized zones are disseminated within the phyllic alteration and
contain abundant pyrite with frequente inclusions of chalcopyrite, sphalerite, galena, monazite,
thorite, Au-Ag tellurides and Au (Ag= 4 to 22 wt.%; Abreu, 2004; Paes de Barros, 2007).
7.4.3 X1 deposit
The X1 deposit (Rodrigues, 2012) is confined to a medium to coarse-grained, equigranular
to porphyritic biotite granodiorite and a quartz-feldspar porphyry of tonalite composition (Figs.
7.7 and 7.8A-B), generally crosscut by mafic dykes. These lithotypes represent moderate to
strongly evolved, oxidized, calc-alkaline, meta- to peraluminous and magnesium to ferrous felsic
magmatism, similar to volcanic arc granitic rocks (I-type granites). SHRIMP U-Pb zircon
geochronology provides crystallization ages of 1,904 ±4.6 Ma and 1,773 ±5.7 Ma, respectively to
the biotite granodiorite and quartz-feldspar porphyry (Assis et al., submitted). Futhermore, the
biotite granodiorite shows TDM that vary from 2.46 to 2.4 Ga and ?Nd(t) between -3.39 and -3.21,
whereas the quartz-feldspar porphyry exhibits younger TDM ages (2.12 to 2.18 Ga) but higher
?Nd(t) values (from -1.7 to -1.38), indicative of Paleoproterozoic juvenile source with crustal
contribution (Assis et al., submitted).
These rocks have been variably affected by the following hydrothermal alteration types: (1)
strong potassic alteration with orthoclase ± hematite, usually lying distal to the mineralized zones
(Fig. 7.8D); (2) phyllic alteration zones with coarse-grained muscovite + quartz + sulfide either
within the core of the granitic host as as alteration halos around quartz-rich veins, but in both cases
as 1 to 30 meters thick alteration zones (Fig. 7.8E); (3) propylitic alteration characterized by
chlorite + epidote + calcite ± apatite ± rutile ± hematite ± pyrite lyting distally to the ore zones
(Fig. 7.8F); (4) a more distal and restricted chloritic alteration; and (5) pervasive to later calcite-
rich veinlets, sometimes with bladed calcite (Rodrigues 2012).
199

The gold mineralization at the X1 deposit is mainly disseminated within the phyllic
alteration zones. The ore paragenesis consists of pyrite + molybdenite ± chalcopyrite ± rutile ±
hematite, with gold grade ranging from 0.5 to 10 g/t. Quartz veins as stockwork ore usually
exhibit a centimetric to metric phyllic alteration halo, have the same sulfide mineral assemblage,
but lower gold contends (<0.2 ppm). Within phyllic altearation, chalcopyrite and molybdenite
generally fill the pyrite, quartz and muscovite interstices, or occur as small inclusions in the pyrite.
Chalcopyrite and molybdenite can also fill some veinlets/veins mostly of pyrite and milky to
translucent quartz. Gold (Ag = 20-30 wt.%) occurs as small inclusions (~20 µm) in pyrite together
with tsumoite (BiTe), hessite (Ag2Te), galena, monazite, sphalerite, apatite and molybdenite.
Fig. 7.7. (A) Geological map of the X1 deposit (modified from Ianhez, 2008); and (B) Geologic cross
section showing the relationship between the units of the X1 deposit and the hydrothermal alteration zones
along A-B (Rodrigues, 2012).
Taken these three gold-rich deposits collectively, fluid inclusion assemblages in quartz from
Pé Quente and X1 deposits reveal basically the coexistence between two difrerent types of fluids:
(1) aqueous two-phase inclusions with wide salinity (2.1-26.1 wt.% eq. NaCl) and homogenization
temperatures ranging from 126.5°C to 268.4°C; and (2) H2O-CO2 (0.35-0.77 g/cm 3 ) inclusions of
low salinity (6.1-8.9 wt.% eq. NaCl) and higher homogenization temperatures (251.6 to 334.6°C).
201
These conclusions are based on fluid inclusion studies that carried out either in quartz from
pervasive sodic alteration zones from Pé Quente as from pervasive phyllic alteration at X1 deposit.
These data are suggestive of heterogeneous entrapment, possibly by immiscibility processes in a
deep magmatic-hydrothermal system. On the Luizão deposit, however, fluid inclusion
assemblages from quartz crystals reveal the predominance of two types of aqueous fluids: (1) a
high salinity (33.6 - 37 wt% NaCl eq.) fluid represented by halite-bearing fluid inclusions with
total homogenization temperatures ranging from 200°C to 280°C; and (2) a low salinity (2.5 – 15
wt% NaCl eq.) and lower temperature fluids (95°C - 185°C), represented by two-phase inclusions
(Assis et al., 2014).

7.6 DISCUSSIONS
7.6.1 Source of ore-forming materials
Since rhenium concentrations remain relatively constant within a reservoir, it can be used to
constrain the source of Re, and therefore, discriminate multiples mineralizing events, spatially
separated but overlapped temporally (Mao et al., 1999). Re concentrations in pyrite from the
Luizão and Pé Quente deposits are<17.5 ppb, whereas in molybdenite Re contents may reach up
to 105,95 ppm( Table 7.3). Molybdenite incorporates into its structure significant Re contents,
usually about percent order (Stain et al., 2001) which is considered three orders of magnitude
higher than those found within pyrite (Re content in ppb range). Thus, according to the Re values
found in X1 deposit (up to 168.6 ppm) we could consider that it had the same rhenium source as
Pé Quente and Luizão deposits, for which the Re contents are smaller about three order of
magnitude. In additionally, the positive correlations obtained for the 187
Os/ 188
Os ratios further
indicate it. Therefore, these features support the interpretation of a unique source to the
hydrothermal-magmatic event responsible for gold mineralization within the AFGP. Similar
conclusions were reported on some granite-hosted gold-rich deposits (Stein et al., 2001; Mao et
al., 2006; Wilson et al., 2007; Lang et al., 2013), however, we point out they were regarded to Re
content in molybdenite from temporally distinct but spatially overlapped mineralizations.
Moreover, Mao et al. (1999) discusses that rhenium contents in molybdenite decrease from
mantle source (10.34 to 1,280 ppm), to mixtures between mantle and crust, and then to crust
(<1.34 ppm), and therefore, can be useful for discriminating its source. The Re contents found in
molybdenite from X1 deposit range from 142.2 to 168.6 ppm, suggesting that the ore-forming
206
materials for this deposit have been mainly originated from mantle source. Thus, assuming a
single source for the hydrothermal-magmatic event within the AFGP, we could suggest that pyrite
crystals from Luizão and Pé Quente deposits show compatible Re concentration for mantle-
derived material. These results are similar to those obtained by Mao et al. (1999) for molybdenite
derived from mantle.
7.6.2 Mineralization age and metallogenetic implications
Altogether, U-Pb zircon dating and Re-Os pyrite-molybdenite ages can be satisfactory used
to link magmatism to mineralization as they yield magmatic emplacement and mineralization ages
of granite-hosted gold deposits. In this view, temporal relationships between ore-forming
processes and magmatic events on some porphyry and granite-hosted gold-rich deposits have been
widely and successfully performed (Valencia et al., 2005; Wilson et al., 2007; Huishou et al.,
2008; Tafti et al., 2009; Xu et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2013; Imer et al., 2013; Mirnejad et al., 2013).
The pyrite and molybdenite Re-Os data reported in this work for three granite-hosted gold
deposits are the first robust geochronological results obtained to constrain the timing of gold
metallogeny in the AFGP. The striking feature shown in this geochronological context is that
pyrite and molybdenite Re-Os ages reveal that gold mineralizations in the easternmost sector of
the province formed within a narrow interval age from 1,805 ±21.5 to 1,782 ±8.2 Ma (Table 7.3),
that remarkably overlaps, within their respective uncertainties, the U-Pb zircon crystallization ages
of the porphyries and subvolcanic interpreted to be part of the Colíder (1,786 ±17 Ma to 1,773
±5.7 Ma) and Teles Pires suites (1,782 ±17 Ma to 1,774 ±7.5 Ma; Table 7.1). Moreover, these data
do indicate that the disseminated gold mineralizations in the AFGP are the product of a single
discrete Paleoproterozoic intrusive event of approximately 10 Ma that occurred during the
Statherian period.
Considering the isotopic uniformity among these deposits as previously discussed that might
reflect a single and similar rhenium source, an isochron age could be obtained for the eight
samples together (six for pyrite and two for molybdenite). Collectively, the data yield a very well-
defined 187
Re- 187
Os isochron age at 1,786 ±1 Ma (MSWD = 2.3; Fig. 7.11A) and a weight average
model age at 1,787 ±3.2 Ma (MSWD = 0.96; Fig. 7.11B), which are proposed in this work as the
age of the main gold mineralization event in the eastern sector of the AFGP. The isochron age
shows an intercept value of 0.0003±0.0016 on the 187
Os axis that is practically zero within the
207
uncertainties. Due molybdenite and pyrite contain low or no non-radiogenic 187
Os values, the
model age obtained by the 187
Re and 187
Os contents are very reliable (Faure, 1986; Selby &
Creaser, 2001; Xu et al., 2012) and therefore can be calculated with the equation: t = (1/?) x
ln(1+ 187
Os/ 187
Re). Additionally, the consistency between the isochron age and the weighted
average model age (within the uncertainties) do indicate that the analytical results are very
believable. Therefore, based on that consistency we assume that the mineralization age for our
disseminated granite-hosted gold deposits is within a range of 1,787 ±3.2 Ma to 1,786 ±1 Ma.
Recetly, similar granite-hosted gold deposits have also been described at the northwestern sector
of the AFGP, int the Juruena gold district, for which Acevedo (2014) reported slightly similar Re-
Os molybdenite age, centered at 1,805 ±7Ma. This study further indicates either a homogeneity
concerning the geological attributes as the same source for the hydrothermal-magmatic gold event
within the province.
Fig. 7.11. Pyrite and molybdenite Re-Os (A) isochron age for the Luizão, Pé Quente and X1 intrusion-
hosted gold deposits and (B) weighted mean model age for the same deposits.
Mafic dikes of unknown age with intense hydrotermal alteration and mineralized with pyrite
± chalcopyrite are constantly observed crosscutting the plutonic and subvolcanic host rocks (Assis
et al., 2014). These dikes may represent mixing of mafic magmas with felsic to intermediate
magmas, and therefore, may represent important keys to the ore-forming processes. Hot mafic
melt injected into colder felsic magmas can trigger vigorous convection and magmatic degassing,
with release of volatiles (F, Cl, S, CO2), and metals to the ore-forming fluids exsolved from the
felsic magma chamber (Seedorff et al., 2005; Silclair, 2007).
208
In a more regional scenario, these mineralizations could also be related to the I-type,
volcanic arc-type Paranaíta suite, dated at 1,816 ±16 to 1,793 ±6 Ma (U-Pb zircon crystallization
ages). However, although these ages are slightly outside the age range obtained for the deposits of
the eastern sector, the rocks belonging to this unit are unknown within the easternmost portion of
the province. For that reason, we do not believe that this unit could be responsible for the timing
of the gold metallogeny within the province.
However, these Re-Os sulfide ages are completely the opposite of the current view proposed
bout the timing of the gold mineralization within the province (Moura, 1998; Paes de Barros,
2007; Silva & Abram, 2008; Miguel Jr., 2011; Xavier et al., 2011; Assis et al., 2014). Based on
relationships between granitic host intrusions and its respective hydrothermal patterns and deposit,
it has been proposed that the disseminated gold-rich deposits from the province would be related
to three granitic intrusion activities: (1) 1.98 to 1.95 Ga, represented by Novo Mundo and Pé
Quente granitic plutons followed by the formation of the Luizão, Edú and Pé Quente deposits,
respectively; (2) 1.89 to 1.87 Ga, referring to Nhandu and Matupá granites, and the generation of
the Serrinha deposit hosted by the Matupá suite (Moura et al., 2006); and (3) 1.77 Ga A2-type
subvolcanics emplacement, with the formation of the Francisco epithermal system (Assis, 2011).
Therefore, the pyrite and molybdenite Re-Os ages in the investigated deposits are
substantially different from the U-Pb crystallization ages of their granitic host intrusions, and so,
there seems to be no genetic connection between intrusive host rocks as suggested by geological
relationships. Thus, those three previously events described, based only on U-Pb zircon
crystallization ages for their ommediate plutonic host, would not related to gold mineralizing
event within the province, but to three major Paleoproterozoic magmatic emplacement (Fig. 7.12).
These magmatic activities would have been responsible only for the emplacement of the granites
host, for which we would have: (1) an Orosirian period, from 1,979 to 1,931 Ma, that represents
the emplacement of I-type Pé Quente monzonite, Novo Mundo and Aragão granites, which
evolved to the emplacement of (2) late Orosinian granodiorite-tonalite adakite-like magmas (Assis
et al., submitted), defined by intrusions with crystallization ages between 1,910 Ma and 1,848 Ma,
in which are included Nhandu pluton, Matupá intrusive suite, X1 granodiorite and União do Norte
granodiorite; and finally a (3) Statherian period, with a narrow age within 1,774 Ma that
corresponds to the emplacement of A2-type União do Norte porphyry. The first two events were
related to the production of oxidized (magnetite-bearing) I-type, calc-alkaline to sub-alkaline,
209
medium to high K, meta- to peraluminous magmas, whereas the third magmatic episode would be
associated to oxidized A2-type, alkaline peraluminous magmas (Table 7.1).

about 205 Ma.
Some of these deposits have been described as belonging to intrusion-related gold systems
(IRGS model) (e.g. Luizão deposit; Paes de Barros, 2007), mesothermal gold deposits (Santos et
al., 2001) or similar to gold-rich porphyry style (e.g. Serrinha, X1 and Pé Quente deposits; Moura
et al., 2006; Assis, 2011; Rodrigues, 2012). However, in the most recent review about their
geological attributes and ore-forming processes, it has been suggested that they are similar to
porphyry-type, but emplaced at deeper crustal levels (Assis et al., 2014). Within this context, the
factors that control the generation and the size of a porphyry deposit are the key points concerning
the understanding of its formation and requires the comprehension of several ore-forming
processes such as number of mineralizing and magmatic events, volume of fluids and elements
budge, source of fluids and metals, role of structures and the duration of the hydrothermal system
(Valencia et al., 2005; Seedofff et al., 2005; Sillittoe, 2010). According to this last key, several
researchers have pointed out that for the Chilean porphyries, multiple but short-lived
hydrothermal-mineralization episodes play an essential role on their construction (Richards et al.,
1999; Makasaev et al., 2004; Valentia et al., 2005; Chiaradia et al., 2013). However, according to
the most recent metallogenetic model adopted for gold mineralization at the AFGP these keys are
not entirely applicable. Although the granite-hosted gold deposits from AFGP might be related to
a major mineralization event, they are product of a short-lived hydrothermal process. Moreover,
211
multiple magmatism events within the deposit scale are described, which include porphyries
emplacement into granitic plutons of different ages and compositions.
6.3 Litogeochemical affinities and implications for tectonic regime
In the eastern sector of the province, the Re-Os ages overlap the U-Pb zircon crystallization
ages reported for both the volcanic and subvolcanic rocks of the Colíder suite (1,786 ±17 Ma to
1,773 ±5.7 Ma) and those of the Teles Pires intrusive suite (1,782 ±17 Ma to 1,774 ±7.5 Ma; Fig.
7.12).
At the three investigated gold deposits subvolcanic intrusions are often present crosscuting
the enclosing granitic rocks and generally associated with the ore zones (Figs. 7.4B and 7.8B-C).
This relationship is best exposed at the X1 deposit (Figs. 7.8B-C), where a quartz-feldspar
porphyry of age at 1,773 ±5.7Ma (Rodrigues, 2012) is one of the main rock host of the gold
mineralization and has been interpreted as belonging to the Colíder suite (Assis et al., submitted).
Moreover, at Pé Quente and Luizão deposits, intermineral and mineralized quartz-feldspar
porphyry dikes are also intrusive into the monzonitic and granitic host rocks, however, in lower
abundance compared to the X1 deposit (Assis, 2011; Stabile, 2012; Trevisan et al., 2013).
Although in these last cases the intrusions have not been dated yet, their geological relationships
together with Re-Os sulfide ages and hydrothermal mineral assemblages further provide a major
Statherian metallogenic event of spatially widespread porphyry-related magmatic-hydrothermal
activity in the Alta Floresta Gold Province (isochron age at 1,786 ±1 Ma; Fig. 7.11A).
The formation of most of the gold deposits in the province have been previously attributed
as part of the development of the Paleoproterozoic volcanic arcs designed as Juruena Magmatic
arc (Moura, 1998; Santos et al., 2001; Souza et al., 2005; Paes de Barros, 2007; Silva & Abram,
2008; Assis, 2011; Rodrigues, 2012; Assis et al., 2014). However, none of them have
convincingly linked yet the ore-forming processes to a volcanic arc activity. However, major and
trace element concentrations for X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (Assis et al., submitted) support an
strongly oxidized and moderately evolved calc-alkaline magma with volcanic arc affinities (I-type
magnetite-bearing granite) to this unit (Fig. 7.13). Currently, these attributes correspond to the
most convincing connection between ore-forming processes and volcanic arc activity to the
disseminated gold-rich deposits from AFGP. Moreover, the Re contents found in molybdenite
from X1 deposit (Table 7.3), suggesting that its ore-forming materials have been mainly
originated from mantle source. According to Assis et al. (submitted), such the host rocks as the X1
212
quartz-feldspar porphyry exhibit absence to low amounts of inherited zircon crystals (ages from
2.03 to 2.06 Ga), also providing a further clue that these lithotypes were mainly originated into a
juvenile arc setting, or at least, far away from older and well-developed terrains.

On the other hand, the Re-Os sulfide ages could be also associated, on a smaller scale, to the
emplacement of subvolcanic rocks from the Teles Pires suite (1.78 to 1.77 Ga), especially if
considered the strong spatial relationship between the Uniao do Norte Porphyry (1,774 ±7.4 Ma;
Miguel-Jr, 2011; Assis et al., 2012) and the Francisco intermediate sulphidation epithermal
deposit (Assis, 2011; Assis et al., 2014). Its whole-rock geochemistry (Assis et al., 2012) supports
an oxidized alkaline A2-type granite affinity, related to a back-arc onset.
213
Within this context, our data allow us to propose that the Paleoproterozoic volcanic arc to
syn-collisional subvolcanic and porphyries from the Colíder suite may have been responsible for
the major hydrothermal system within the province, which are closely associated to the
disseminated granite-hosted gold deposits, whereas the rocks from Teles Pires suite might host or
even participate in the ore-forming processes only regarding to epithermal-related gold systems.
The plutonic-volcanic rocks of the easternmost segment of the AFGP can be individualized
into three major Paleoproterozoic tectono-magmatic stages based on volcanic arcs models: (Stage
I, 2.1-1.95 Ga): Orosirian Cuiú-Cuiú magmatic arc, responsible for emplacement of granitic
basement and Old granites (e.g. Pé Quente monzonite, and Novo Mundo granite); (Stage II, 1.9-
1.8 Ga): Early Juruena magmatic arc during the late Orosirian period, with the emplacement of
Nhandu, Aragão, Matupá and Juruena granites; and finally the (Stage III, 1.78-1.75 Ga) Statherian
post-collisional Juruena magmatic arc responsible for the emplacement of I- and A2-typies
porphyries and subvolcanics rocks (Assis et al., submitted). Therefore, within a more regional
geological context, we suggest that the Statherian Re-Os ages from 1,787 ±6.2 to 1,786 ± 4.9
(isochron age of 1,785 ±1 Ma; Figs. 7.10 and 7.11A), as the major timing of the gold metallogeny
within the province. That timing would be associated to the beginning of Stage III, during the
earlier stages of emplacement of the Colíder suite (~1.78 to 1.77 Ga), into a volcanic arc-type
onset toward a more evolved plataform. Based on the data previously discussed, we interpret this
geodynamic setting as the responsible for the ore-forming processes that took place at the
province. On the other hand, the plutonic host rocks would have been entirely formed within a
volacanic arc-like setting, during the first two stages.
Finally, these new Re-Os pyrite and molybdenite ages suggest that gold exploration in the
eastern sector of the AFGP should perhaps be more focused on plutonic suites temporally related
to the Colíder and Teles Pires suites. In the northwestern sector of the province, on the other,
plutono-volcanic rocks of the Paranaita suite become prime targets.
C o n cl u s i o n s
The following conclusions can be made based on the data presented:
(1) The high and uniform Re contents found in pyrite and molybdenite grains suggest a
mantle-derive material for the genesis of the major disseminated granite-hosted gold deposits from
the AFGP.
214
(2) The Re-Os pyrite model ages obtained for the Pé Quente deposit are between 1,792 ±9
Ma and 1,784 ±11 Ma, whereas those for the Luizão deposit vary from 1,790 ±9 Ma to 1,782 ±9
Ma, with 187
Re/ 187
Os weight average model age at 1,787 ±5.5 Ma and 1,787 ±6.2 Ma,
respectively. The Re-Os molybdenite model ages for the X1 deposit range from 1,787 ±7 Ma to
1,785 ±7 Ma, with weighted average model age at 1,786 ±5 Ma.
(3) Based on the uniformity of the Re and Os contents, the Re-Os sulfide ages, such in the
deposit scale as among them, we obtained a very well-defined Re-Os isochron sulfide age at 1,786
±1 Ma (weight average model age = 1,787 ±3.2 Ma) for the timing of those deposits. These ages
indicate a Statherian major, narrow and single gold metallogenetic event that took place at the
province, which lasted approximately 10 Ma and not marked by multiple magmatic stages as
previously believed.
(4) The pyrite and molybdenite Re-Os ages in the investigated deposits are substantially
different from the ages of their immediate felsic intrusive host rocks, except in the case of the X1
deposit, where the age of the quartz-feldspar porphyry overlaps the molybdenite Re-Os ages.
Therefore, there is no genetic connection between ore-forming processes and tonalitic plutonism
as previously thought.
(5) Our Re-Os sulfide ages do demonstrate the contemporaneity between the mineralization
and porphyries emplacement found at the major disseminated granite-hosted gold deposits in the
province, which belong to Colíder suite (1.78 to 1.77 Ga). These relationships are best observed
between the mineralized zones and X1 quartz-feldspar porphyry (1,773 ±5.7Ma) found at X1
deposit and support the conclusion of porphyry-related magmatic-hydrothermal activity within the
province. On a smaller scale, the Re-Os sulfide ages could be also associated to the emplacement
of the subvolcanic rocks from the Teles Pires suite (1.78 to 1.77 Ga), mainly if considered the
Francisco intermediate sulphidation epithermal system.
(6) This conclusion is completely the opposite of the current view proposed to the timing of
gold metallogeny within the province, which was based on three granitic intrusion activities: 1.98-
1.95 Ga, 1.89-1.87 Ga and ~1.77 Ga. However, we propose that these magmatic events were only
related to three major Paleoproterozoic magmatic periods of production and emplacement of I-
type plutonic host rocks.
215
(7) Based on geochemical signature, the subvolcanic rocks belonging to Colíder suite show
a strongly oxidized, calc-alkaline volcanic arc-type affinity, whereas those form Teles Pires suite
exhibit an oxidized alkaline A2-type granite affinity associated to a back-arc onset.
(8) Our data data suggest the rocks belonging to the third magmatic event (Assis et al.,
submitted), mainly those from Colíder suite, were the causative event to the generation of the
granite-hosted gold deposits of the province.
(9) Therefore, our results indicate that the timing of the gold metallogeny within the
province migh be related to the early stages of the post-collisional Juruena magmatic arc setting
(Stage III proposted by Assis et al. submitted), from 1.78 to 1.75 Ga.
(10) These Re-Os pyrite and molybdenite ages open new perspectives for gold exploration
in the province as widespread plutonic suites, such as those temporally related to Colíder and
Teles Pires intrusive suite, now become prime targets.

CAPÍTULO 8 .
Geocronologia 40Ar/39Ar da alteração
hidrotermal.
O entendimento da história termal-tectônica em terrenos que hospedam mineralizações
auríferas em sistemas graníticos é essencial na compreensão da história de resfriamento e
exumação desses depósitos, assim como na do ambiente geodinâmico regional. Neste contexto,
esse capítulo destina-se à apresentação e discussão dos dados geocronológicos 40
Ar/ 39
Ar obtidos
em silicatos da alteração hidrotermal proximal às zonas mineralizadas dos depósitos X1, Pé
Quente, Luizão e Francisco.
Na Província, apenas um trabalho até o momento reportou idades dessa natureza (Silva &
Abram, 2008), porém, dos quatro depósitos/garimpos estudados, apenas um deles (depósito
Trairão, Silva & Abram, 2008; Dias, 2012) não mostrou indícios de abertura do sistema isotópico,
com consequente perda de argônio decorrente de evento tectono-termal (orogenia Sunsás?). As
idades 40
Ar/ 39
Ar obtidas no escopo do trabalho de Silva & Abram (2008) estiveram na ordem de:
(1) 1.787 ±8 a 1.784 ±8 em muscovita/sericita hidrotermal do depósito do Trairão; (2) 1.394 ±7 a
1.308 ±7 provenientes de biotita e sericita/muscovita do depósito Tapajós; (3) 1.471 ±7 a 1.469 ±8
Ma em muscovita do depósito Paraíba; e (4) 1.260 ±6 a 1.350 ±7 Ma em sericita/muscovita do
garimpo do Gil e Fabinho. Deste conjunto de idades, apenas as duas primeiras provém de
depósitos auríferos disseminados em rochas de composição granítica, enquanto as demais são
oriundas de depósitos/garimpos auríferos filonares encaixados em metavulcânicas ou em unidades
do embasamento (Abram & Silva, 2008).
Neste cenário, os dados aqui obtidos têm por objetivos principais a caracterização: (1) das
idades 40
Ar/ 39
Ar da alteração hidrotermal dos depósitos auríferos disseminados em sistemas
graníticos e (2) da primeira idade da alteração hidrotermal associada ao minério do depósito
epitermal do Francisco, visto que em decorrência da baixa concentração de Re (? 0,06 ppb) em
cistais de pirita provenientes das zonas mineralizadas do depósito, a geocronologia Re-Os não foi
passível de ser efetuada. A partir desses dados, será possível uma melhor compreensão quanto à
duração do evento hidrotermal (a partir dos dados 40
Ar/ 39
Ar) e mineralizante (comparação com as
idades Re-Os obtidas em sulfetos) da província, em especial, na sua compartimentação leste.

Depósito X1
Para o depósito X1 foram analisados dois concentrados de muscovita provenientes de suas
zonas de alteração fílica (Tabelas 8.1). Para todas essas amostras foram efetuadas 15 etapas de
aquecimento a intervalos de 0,2W de potência de operação do laser.
Para a amostra FX1D-43-A20 foram selecionadas três alíquotas constituídas por grãos
individuais de muscovita. Os grãos 3 e 4 forneceram idades plateau paleoproterozóicas muito
semelhantes, em 1.733,3 ±6,3 e 1.736,3 ±6,7 Ma (erro médio em 0,4% para 1?; Figs. 8.1A-B),
respectivamente com 91% e 94% de 39
Ar liberado. O grão 1, contudo, forneceu idade plateau
ligeiramente mais antiga, em torno de 1.747,3 ±6.0 Ma, com 89% de 39
Ar liberado (Fig. 8.1C).
A amostra FX1D-41-A22 por sua vez, contou com a individualização de três alíquotas de
muscovita grossa, as quais forneceram idades plateau coesas e similares em 1.750,5 ±6,1 Ma,
1.751,4 ±6,2 Ma e 1.748,8 ±6,2 Ma (erro médio de 0,35% para 1?; Figs. 8.1D-F), com 78%, 84% e
60% de 39
Ar liberado, respectivamente.
Depósito Pé Quente
Foram selecionados três concentrados minerais no depósito Pé Quente (Tabela 8.1), um
deles correspondente a cristais de muscovita oriundos de injeção de muscovita pegmatito (Fig.
4.4C) no biotita tonalito Pé Quente com forte a moderada alteração potássica pervasiva.
As quatro alíquotas originárias do concentrado de muscovita da injeção de pegmatito
(amostra FD.11-87,65) corresponderam a grãos individuais de granulação grossa, que foram
analisados em 15 etapas de aquecimento gradual a 0,2W de potência do laser. No conjunto, todas
as alíquotas fornecem idades no Orosiriano, sendo que duas delas (alíquotas 1 e 3) indicam idades
plateau ligeiramente mais antigas: de 1.852,2 ±6,3 e 1.853,2 ±6,3 Ma (Figs. 8.2A-B); enquanto as
alíquotas 2 e 4 forneceram idades plateau de 1.844,2 ±6,3 e 1.843,5 ±6,4 Ma (Figs. 8.2C-D).

Apenas uma amostra de sericita originárias do halo sericítico do depósito do Francisco foi

Ar/ 39

obtidas idades plateau para nenhuma delas.
Para a amostra FNV.05-83,45, três grãos de feldspato potássico foram analisados entre 15 e

integração das idades obtidas para os grãos 2 e 4 mostram certa uniformidade, embora não se
